module.description: This PrepTest contains three scored LSAT sections  plus an additional section to simulate the unscored section in a real LSAT administration. Practice as if taking an actual test by following the test-taking instructions and timing yourself.

sections.directions: Directions: Each set of questions in this section is based on a single passage or a pair of passages. The questions are to be answered on the basis of what is stated or implied in the passage or pair of passages. For some questions, more than one of the choices could conceivably answer the question. However, you are to choose the best answer; that is, choose the response that most accurately and completely answers the question.

items.stimulusText:
Charles Darwin objected to all attempts to reduce his theory of evolution to its doctrine of natural selection. "Natural selection has been the main but not the exclusive means of modification," he declared. Nonetheless, a group of self-proclaimed strict constructionist Darwinians has recently risen to prominence by reducing Darwin's theory in just this way. These theorists use the mechanism of natural selection to explain all biological phenomena; they assert that natural selection is responsible for every aspect of every species' form and behavior, and for the success or failure of species in general.

Natural selection is generally held to result in adaptation, the shaping of an organism's form and behavior in response to environmental conditions to achieve enhanced reproductive success. If the strict constructionists are right, the persistence of every attribute and the survival of every species are due to such adaptation. But in fact, nature provides numerous examples of attributes that are not adaptations for reproductive success and of species whose success or failure had little to do with their adaptations.

For example, while it is true that some random mutations of genetic material produce attributes that enhance reproductive success and are thus favored by natural selection, and others produce harmful attributes that are weeded out, we now know from population genetics that most mutations fall into neither category. Research has revealed that neutral, nonadaptive changes account to a large extent for the evolution of DNA. Most substitutions of one unit of DNA for another within a population have no effect on reproductive success. These alterations often change the attributes of species, but their persistence from one generation to the next is not explainable by natural selection.

Additionally, the study of mass extinctions in paleontology has undermined the strict constructionist claim that natural selection can account for every species' success or failure. The extinction of the dinosaurs some 65 million years ago was probably caused by the impact of an extraterrestrial body. Smaller animal species are generally better able to survive the catastrophic changes in climate that we would expect to follow from such an impact, and mammals in the Cretaceous period were quite small because they could not compete on the large scale of the dominant dinosaurs. But while this scenario explains why dinosaurs died off and mammals fared relatively well, it does not conform to the strict constructionist view of the adaptive reasons for the success of species. For that view assumes that adaptations are a response to conditions that are already in place at the time the adaptations occur, and mammals could not have adapted in advance to conditions caused by the impact. In a sense, their success was the result of dumb luck.
items.stemText: Which one of the following most accurately expresses the main point of the passage?

options.optionContent: Evidence from two areas of science undermines the strict constructionist claim that natural selection is the only driving force behind evolution.
According to strict constructionist Darwinians, new evidence suggests that natural selection is responsible for the failure of most extinct species.
New evidence demonstrates that natural selection can produce nonadaptive as well as adaptive changes.
Strict constructionist followers of Darwin maintain that natural selection is responsible for all evolutionary change.
Evidence from the study of population genetics helps to disprove the claim that natural selection results in the survival of the fittest species.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This is the best choice. The main point of this passage is to debunk the strict constructionist understanding (that evolution can be explained entirely by natural selection). The author uses examples from two areas of science (DNA mutation and mass extinction) to prove this point.

This conflicts with the passage. Strict constructionists believe that natural selection is responsible for the failure of **all** extinct species. Also, notice that no specific *new evidence* is introduced in the passage; the author debunks the strict constructionist view with only vague reference to past research.

This conflicts with the passage. The passage uses nonadaptive change as evidence that all evolution *isn’t* produced by natural selection. Also, notice that no specific *new* evidence is introduced in the passage; the author debunks the strict constructionist view with only vague reference to past research.

This is too narrow to be the main point of the passage. While this is true, it is stated clearly in the first paragraph. The remainder of the passage works to refute this strict constructionist viewpoint.
This is too narrow to be the main point of the passage. Evidence from the study of population genetics is only one of multiple arguments used to refute the claims of strict constructionists.

items.displayType: Identifying Main Points and Primary Purposes

items.stemText: According to the author, mammals were able to survive catastrophic environmental changes that occurred roughly 65 million years ago because they

options.optionContent: had adapted previously to similar changes
were relatively small
were highly intelligent
lived in a wide range of environments
were able to reproduce quickly

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This isn’t supported by the passage. There is no mention in the passage of similar catastrophic changes. Instead, the passage suggests mammals survived due to their size.
This is the best choice. The passage notes that “Smaller animal species are generally better able to survive . . . catastrophic changes in climate”. It was mammals’ size that enabled them to survive.
This isn’t supported by the passage. Intelligence was not mentioned as a factor that might have helped mammals survive catastrophic climate change.

This isn’t supported by the passage. Mammals and dinosaurs were in competition, according to the passage, which suggests that they shared environments. Instead, the passage suggests mammals survived due to their small size.
This isn’t supported by the passage. Reproduction rate is not mentioned as a factor that might have enabled mammals to survive catastrophic climate change.

items.stemText: The author asserts which one of the following regarding mutations of genetic material?

options.optionContent: The majority of such mutations are not passed on to subsequent generations.
The majority of such mutations occur during periods when mass extinctions take place.
The majority of such mutations change species' behavior rather than their appearance.
The majority of such mutations have no effect on reproductive success.
The majority of such mutations occur in larger rather than smaller species.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This conflicts with the passage. According to the passage, many nonadaptive changes *are* passed on from one generation to the next, though “their persistence from one generation to the next is not explainable by natural selection.”
This isn’t supported by the passage. The passage doesn’t specify when mutations might occur and doesn’t relate nonadaptive changes to mass extinctions at all.
This isn’t supported by the passage. The passage doesn’t say whether most mutations are behavioral or formal.

This is the best choice. The passage tells us that most genetic changes are neither positive or negative: “most substitutions of one unit of DNA for another within a population have no effect on reproductive success.”
This isn’t supported by the passage. The author doesn’t make any distinctions about how physical size might affect number of mutations in a species.

items.stemText: The author would be most likely to agree with which one of the following statements?

options.optionContent: Natural selection is responsible for almost none of the characteristics of existing species.
The fact that a species flourishes in a certain environment is not proof of its adaptation to that environment.
Only evolutionary changes that provide some advantage to a species are transmitted to subsequent generations.
Large animal species are generally unable to survive in harsh environmental conditions.
Natural selection is useful for explaining the form but not the behavior of most species.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This choice goes much further than what the author says in the passage. The passage states that natural selection isn’t responsible for *all* of species’ traits. We can infer that the author still believes a good deal of characteristics of species **are** due to natural selection.

This is the best choice. In the final paragraph, the author writes that “mammals could not have adapted in advance to conditions caused by the impact.” And yet, mammals flourished in the aftermath of the environmental change. From this example, we can infer that the author believes that a species can flourish in an environment that it is not adapted to.
This contradicts the passage. The author asserts that *most* of the traits transmitted to subsequent generations *don’t* provide any advantage.

This isn’t supported by the passage. The passage states that smaller animals are better equipped to handle “catastrophic changes in climate”, but it doesn’t assert that larger animals are unable to survive harsh conditions in general.
This isn’t supported by the passage. The author describes natural selection as a factor, though *not* the only factor, in the accumulation of both physical and behavioral traits.

items.stemText: The author's stance toward the arguments of the strict constructionist Darwinians can most accurately be described as one of

options.optionContent: emphatic disagreement
mild disapproval
open-minded neutrality
conditional agreement
unreserved endorsement

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This is the best choice. The author of the passage strongly disagrees with the strict constructionist Darwinians, and the passage is a refutation of their arguments. The author characterizes the claims of strict constructionists as fundamentally conflicting with the intent of Darwin’s theory.

This isn’t strong enough to describe the author’s stance. We can tell from the passage that the author emphatically rejects the claims of the strict constructionists. “Mild disapproval” doesn’t capture the extent of author’s disagreement.
This conflicts with the passage. Far from expressing “neutrality”, the author presents strong disapproval of the strict constructionists’ arguments.

This conflicts with the passage. The author doesn’t agree with the strict constructionists, nor do they discuss the possibility of agreement. Instead, they express strong rejection of the claims of the strict constructionists.
This conflicts with the passage. “Unreserved endorsement” means “strong agreement”. The author, on the other hand, expresses strong **disagreement** with the arguments of the strict constructionists.

items.stemText: Which one of the following most accurately and completely describes the function of the second paragraph of the passage?

options.optionContent: It outlines the objections to traditional evolutionary theory raised by the strict constructionists mentioned in the first paragraph.
It lists recent evidence suggesting that the strict constructionist claims described in the first paragraph are incorrect.
It describes the strict constructionists' view of evolutionary theory in order to explain why the evidence described in subsequent paragraphs has recently gotten so much attention.
It enumerates the arguments for the strict constructionist position that are rebutted in the paragraphs that follow.
It explains the ramifications of the strict constructionists' claims and helps clarify the relevance of evidence offered in subsequent paragraphs.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This isn’t the function of the second paragraph. It doesn’t outline any objection to traditional evolutionary theory. Rather, it prepares readers for the examples that follow, which refute the *strict constructionists' arguments*.

This isn’t the function of the second paragraph. It doesn’t list any recent evidence, even though it does **introduce** why evidence which comes in the following paragraphs will be relevant (it will debunk the strict constructionist viewpoint).
This isn’t the function of the second paragraph. The second paragraph never mentions the “attention” received by the evidence presented in the rest of the passage.

This isn’t the function of the second paragraph. Rather than “enumerate the arguments” for the strict constructionist position, it explains the ultimate conclusion resulting from the strict constructionist viewpoint. In fact, the passage doesn’t present any arguments *for* the strict constructionist position.

This is the best choice. The function of the paragraph is to explain the ultimate conclusion resulting from the strict constructionists’ claims and to preface the relevance of the examples that follow, which refute those claims.

items.stemText: The primary purpose of the passage is to

options.optionContent: argue in favor of a recently proposed hypothesis
summarize a contemporary debate
demonstrate that a particular view is incorrect
criticize the proponents of a traditional theory
explain why a particular theory is gaining popularity

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This isn’t the purpose of the passage. The passage doesn’t “argue in favor” of any recently proposed hypothesis. Rather, it “refutes” the hypothesis of the strict constructionists.
This isn’t the purpose of the passage. Rather than summarize a debate, the passage attempts to convince the reader that one side of a debate is correct and the other side is incorrect.
This is the best choice. The purpose of the passage is to show readers that the view of the strict constructionists is incorrect.

This isn’t the purpose of the passage. The passage doesn’t “criticize the proponents” of a theory, but rather it demonstrates that a theory is incorrect. In addition, nothing in the passage suggests that the strict constructionist view is traditional (it has “recently risen to prominence”).
This isn’t the purpose of the passage. The purpose of the passage is to show that a theory is incorrect, not to explain the reasons for its popularity.

items.questionType: Identifying Main Points and Primary Purposes
items.displayType: Identifying Main Points and Primary Purposes

items.stimulusText:
From a critical discussion of the work of Victorian photographer Julia Margaret Cameron.

What Cameron called her "fancy-subject" pictures—photographs in which two or more costumed sitters enacted, under Cameron's direction, scenes from the Bible, mythology, Shakespeare, or Tennyson—bear unmistakable traces of the often comical conditions under which they were taken. In many respects they have more connection to the family album pictures of recalcitrant relatives who have been herded together for the obligatory group picture than they do to the masterpieces of Western painting. In Raphael and Giotto there are no infant Christs whose faces are blurred because they moved, or who are looking at the viewer with frank hatred. These traces, of course, are what give the photographs their life and charm. If Cameron had succeeded in her project of making seamless works of illustrative art, her work would be among the curiosities of Victorian photography—like Oscar Gustave Rejlander's extravagantly awful The Two Ways of Life—rather than among its most vital images.

It is precisely the camera's realism—its stubborn obsession with the surface of things—that has given Cameron's theatricality and artificiality its atmosphere of truth. It is the truth of the sitting, rather than the fiction which all the dressing up was in aid of, that wafts out of these wonderful and strange, not-quite-in-focus photographs. They are what they are: pictures of housemaids and nieces and husbands and village children who are dressed up as Mary Madonnas and infant Jesuses and John the Baptists and Lancelots and Guineveres and trying desperately hard to sit still. The way each sitter endures his or her ordeal is the collective action of the photograph, its "plot" so to speak. When we look at a narrative painting we can suspend our disbelief; when we look at a narrative photograph we cannot. We are always aware of the photograph's doubleness—of each figure's imaginary and real personas. Theater can transcend its doubleness, can make us believe (for at least some of the time) that we are seeing only Lear or Medea. Still photographs of theatrical scenes can never escape being pictures of actors.

What gives Cameron's pictures of actors their special quality—their status as treasures of photography of an unfathomably peculiar sort—is their singular combination of amateurism and artistry. In The Passing of Arthur, for example, the mast and oar of the makeshift boat representing a royal barge are obviously broomsticks and the water is white muslin drapery. But these details are insignificant. For once, the homely truth of the sitting gives right of place to the romantic fantasy of its director. The picture, a night scene, is magical and mysterious. While Cameron's fancy-subject pictures have been compared to poor amateur theatricals, The Passing of Arthur puts one in mind of good amateur theatricals one has seen, and recalls with shameless delight.
items.stemText: Which one of the following most accurately expresses the main point of the passage?

options.optionContent: The circumstances under which Cameron's fancy-subject pictures were taken render them unintentionally comical.
The peculiar charm of Cameron's fancy-subject pictures derives from the viewer's simultaneous awareness of the fictional scene portrayed and the circumstances of its portrayal.
The implicit claim of Cameron's fancy-subject pictures to comparison with the masterpieces of Western painting is undermined by the obtrusiveness of the sitters.
The most successful of Cameron's fancy-subject pictures from an aesthetic point of view are those in which the viewer is completely unaware that the sitters are engaged in role playing.
The interest of Cameron's fancy-subject pictures consists in what they tell us about the sitters and not in the imaginary scenes they portray.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This isn’t the main point of the passage. While there may be a comical element to Cameron’s work, the broader point that the passage makes is that the artistic value of the fancy-subject pictures comes from both the circumstances of their creation **as well as** the epic scenes that they portray.

This is the main point of the passage. The passage argues that Cameron’s work inspires delight by combining mythical scenes with the mundane idiosyncrasies of photographic flaws: “These traces, of course, are what give the photographs their life and charm.”

This is too narrow to be the main point of the passage. While the passage does suggest Cameron’s theatrical subjects are limited by the intrusion of the sitter’s “real” self, this is only part of the broader identification of the merits of Cameron’s pictures. They may not compare to masterpieces of painting, but they excel as documents of the photography process.

This contradicts the passage. In fact, the passage argues that, for pictures in which the viewer is **aware** of the sitters’ role playing, “These traces, of course, are what give the photographs their life and charm.” It is this “doubleness” that is the most successful element of Cameron’s work.
This conflicts with the passage. The passage argues that it is the *juxtaposition* of the imaginary scenes **with** the sitters’ that gives the pictures their power.

In The Passing of Arthur, for example, the mast and oar of the makeshift boat representing a royal barge are obviously broomsticks and the water is white muslin drapery. But these details are insignificant. For once, the homely truth of the sitting gives right of place to the romantic fantasy of its director. The picture, a night scene, is magical and mysterious. While Cameron's fancy-subject pictures have been compared to poor amateur theatricals, The Passing of Arthur puts one in mind of good amateur theatricals one has seen, and recalls with shameless delight.
items.stemText: The author mentions the props employed in The Passing of Arthur as

options.optionContent: examples of amateurish aspects of the work
evidence of the transformative power of theater
testimonies to Cameron's ingenuity
indications that the work is intended ironically
support for a negative appraisal of the work

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This is the best choice. The passage mentions the props in *The Passing of Arthur* as an example of an element of fancy-subject pictures that is similar to an amateurish theater production.

This isn’t the purpose of the reference. Given the context, the example of the props in *The Passing of Arthur* illustrates the amateurish qualities of Cameron’s photographs, **not** the transformative power of theater.
This isn’t the purpose of the reference. The props in *The Passing of Arthur* are an example of an amateurish aspect of Cameron’s work, **not** her ingenuity.
This choice is in conflict with the passage. Nothing in the example of the props in *The Passing of Arthur* (or anything else in the passage) suggests that Cameron’s work was intended ironically.

This choice contradicts the passage. Far from negatively appraising the work, the author of the passage delights in the amateurish aspect of the props in *The Passing of Arthur*, likening them to fond memories of amateur theater productions.

items.stimulusText:
From a critical discussion of the work of Victorian photographer Julia Margaret Cameron.

What Cameron called her "fancy-subject" pictures—photographs in which two or more costumed sitters enacted, under Cameron's direction, scenes from the Bible, mythology, Shakespeare, or Tennyson—bear unmistakable traces of the often comical conditions under which they were taken. In many respects they have more connection to the family album pictures of recalcitrant relatives who have been herded together for the obligatory group picture than they do to the masterpieces of Western painting. In Raphael and Giotto there are no infant Christs whose faces are blurred because they moved, or who are looking at the viewer with frank hatred. These traces, of course, are what give the photographs their life and charm. If Cameron had succeeded in her project of making seamless works of illustrative art, her work would be among the curiosities of Victorian photography—like Oscar Gustave Rejlander's extravagantly awful The Two Ways of Life—rather than among its most vital images.

It is precisely the camera's realism—its stubborn obsession with the surface of things—that has given Cameron's theatricality and artificiality its atmosphere of truth. It is the truth of the sitting, rather than the fiction which all the dressing up was in aid of, that wafts out of these wonderful and strange, not-quite-in-focus photographs. They are what they are: pictures of housemaids and nieces and husbands and village children who are dressed up as Mary Madonnas and infant Jesuses and John the Baptists and Lancelots and Guineveres and trying desperately hard to sit still. The way each sitter endures his or her ordeal is the collective action of the photograph, its "plot" so to speak. When we look at a narrative painting we can suspend our disbelief; when we look at a narrative photograph we cannot. We are always aware of the photograph's doubleness—of each figure's imaginary and real personas. Theater can transcend its doubleness, can make us believe (for at least some of the time) that we are seeing only Lear or Medea. Still photographs of theatrical scenes can never escape being pictures of actors.

What gives Cameron's pictures of actors their special quality—their status as treasures of photography of an unfathomably peculiar sort—is their singular combination of amateurism and artistry. In The Passing of Arthur, for example, the mast and oar of the makeshift boat representing a royal barge are obviously broomsticks and the water is white muslin drapery. But these details are insignificant. For once, the homely truth of the sitting gives right of place to the romantic fantasy of its director. The picture, a night scene, is magical and mysterious. While Cameron's fancy-subject pictures have been compared to poor amateur theatricals, The Passing of Arthur puts one in mind of good amateur theatricals one has seen, and recalls with shameless delight.
items.stemText: Which one of the following, if true, would most help to explain the claim about suspension of disbelief (near the middle of the second paragraph)?

options.optionContent: Sitting for a painting typically takes much longer than sitting for a photograph.
Paintings, unlike photographs, can depict obviously impossible situations.
All of the sitters for a painting do not have to be present at the same time.
A painter can suppress details about a sitter that are at odds with an imaginary persona.
Paintings typically bear the stylistic imprint of an artist, school, or period.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: If true, this statement doesn’t help explain the claim about “suspension of disbelief”. If anything, the long time duration required to sit for a painting should give paintings **less** of a natural feeling and be **less** believable.

If true, this statement doesn’t help explain the claim about “suspension of disbelief”. If anything, the ability of paintings to depict impossible scenarios would make them **harder** to believe, which conflicts with claim in the passage.

If true, this statement doesn’t help explain the claim about “suspension of disbelief”. The number of models sitting for a painting doesn’t have anything to do with the eventual believability of the painting.

This is the best choice. If this statement is true, we can imagine that a painter might choose to suppress some details about a sitter to make the painting more believable, perhaps by giving them a more appropriate facial expression. This would make the painting more believable than a photograph in which the sitter looks bored or distracted.

If true, this statement doesn’t help explain the claim about “suspension of disbelief”. If anything, this statement serves to **weaken** the claim made in the passage—if paintings bear stylistic imprints of the conditions of their creation, then it might be **harder** to believe the mythical or historical scenes that they portray.

items.stemText: Based on the passage, Cameron is most like which one of the following in relation to her fancy-subject pictures?

options.optionContent: a playwright who introduces incongruous elements to preserve an aesthetic distance between characters and audience
a rap artist whose lyrics are designed to subvert the meaning of a song sampled in his recording
a sculptor whose works possess a certain grandeur even though they are clearly constructed out of ordinary objects
an architect whose buildings are designed to be as functional as possible
a film director who employs ordinary people as actors in order to give the appearance of a documentary

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This isn’t an analogous relation. Cameron doesn’t preserve a distance between characters and audience. In fact, the ordinariness of the sitters allows viewers to relate to the photographs.

This isn’t an analogous relation. For this relation to be analogous, Cameron’s methods and materials would have to have been *designed* to undercut the scenes portrayed in her work. Cameron, however, earnestly wished to portray biblical and mythical scenes—we have no reason to believe she sought to subvert them.

This relation is analogous to Cameron’s relation to her work. Her success **despite** her humble costumes and models is like this sculptor’s success **despite** the ordinary objects they use in construction.
This isn’t an analogous relation. For this relation to be analogous, Cameron’s work would have to be highly functional, whereas the passage portrays it as highly decorative.

This isn’t an analogous relation. This choice might be tempting, because it involves employing “ordinary people”. But in this statement, the purpose of employing ordinary people is to give the appearance of a documentary, whereas in the case of Cameron, it was not for effect but rather for a lack of alternatives.

items.stemText: Based on the passage, the author would agree with each of the following statements except:

options.optionContent: A less realistic medium can be more conducive to suspension of disbelief than a more realistic medium.
Amateurishness is a positive quality in some works of art.
What might appear to be an incongruity in a narrative photograph can actually enhance its aesthetic value.
We are sometimes aware of both the real and the imaginary persona of an actor in a drama.
A work of art succeeds only to the extent that it realizes the artist's intentions.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: The author would agree with this choice. The passage states that painting is less realistic than photography **and** that painting is more conducive to the suspension of disbelief than photography is. Therefore, we can infer the author believes less realistic media can be more conducive to the suspension of disbelief.

The author would agree with this choice. The author regards amateurishness as a positive quality both in Cameron’s *The Passing of Arthur* and in “good amateur theatricals” mentioned in the final paragraph.

The author would agree with this choice. In fact, this underlies the main point of the passage, which argues that the incongruity in Cameron’s narrative photography actually enhances its aesthetic value.

The author would agree with this choice. The passage says, “We are always aware of the photograph's doubleness—of each figure's imaginary and real personas.” We can infer that the author thinks similarly about actors in a drama and actors in a photograph, in that viewers are aware of both their real and imaginary personas. The passage states that theater only transcends doubleness “some of the time”.

This is the best choice, because we can infer the author would *disagree* with it. While the intention of Cameron’s fancy-subject pictures might have been a straightforward depiction of mythical scenes, the passage argues that Cameron succeeded in producing an effect far beyond the artist’s intention.

items.stemText: The passage provides the most support for inferring that in Cameron's era

options.optionContent: there was little interest in photographs documenting contemporary life
photography was practiced mainly by wealthy amateurs
publicity stills of actors were coming into vogue
there were no professional artist's models
the time required to take a picture was substantial

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This isn’t supported by the passage. The passage discusses some of the works produced by a single photographer, but doesn’t suggest anything about general trends in photography at the time.
This isn’t supported by the passage, which focuses on a single photographer’s work. The passage doesn’t give any more general information about most photographers at the time.
This isn’t supported by the passage. The passage makes no mention of publicity stills of actors, and Cameron’s own work, which employed actors, was very different from publicity stills.
This can’t be inferred from the passage. While Cameron’s work relied on ordinary people instead of professional models, the passage doesn’t suggest that there were no professional models to be found.
This is the best choice. The passage describes the actors in photographs as “trying desperately hard to sit still”, implying that taking a picture was not the quick snap that it is today.

items.stemText: The discussion of suspension of disbelief in the second paragraph serves which one of the following purposes?

options.optionContent: It is the main conclusion of the passage, for which the discussion of Cameron's fancy-subject pictures serves as a case study.
It introduces a contrast the author uses in characterizing the peculiar nature of our response to Cameron's fancy-subject pictures.
It is the key step in an argument supporting the author's negative appraisal of the project of narrative photography.
It is used to explain a criticism of Cameron's fancy-subject pictures that the author shows to be conceptually confused.
It draws a contrast between narrative painting and drama to support the author's conclusion that Cameron's fancy-subject pictures are more like the former.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This isn’t supported. The point about the suspension of disbelief is not the main conclusion of the passage. The main point of the passage is to critique Cameron’s fancy-subject pictures, and the point about the suspension of disbelief is just one conclusion in that undertaking.

This is the best choice. The discussion of the suspension of disbelief helps us better understand the unusual effect Cameron’s fancy-subject pictures have on the viewer by pointing out a key difference between painting and photography. In photography, the ability to entertain fantasy is limited by the real human beings that appear in the work.
This contradicts the passage. Far from giving a negative appraisal of narrative photography, the author of the passage delights in the contrasts that it can produce.

This isn’t the purpose of the discussion. The author doesn’t present (or refute) any criticism of Cameron’s work. The discussion of the “suspension of disbelief” is part of the author’s own argument about unique elements of photography that elicit a unique reaction in viewers.

This conflicts with the passage. The purpose of the discussion is to highlight a key difference between narrative painting and **narrative photography**. Only later in the passage does the author compare Cameron’s work to theatrical works.

items.stemText: The main purpose of the passage is

options.optionContent: to chronicle Cameron's artistic development as a photographer, which culminated in her masterpiece The Passing of Arthur
to argue that the tension between Cameron's aims and the results she achieved in some of her works enhances the works' aesthetic value
to show that Cameron's essentially theatrical vision accounts for both the strengths and the weaknesses of her photographic oeuvre
to explain why Cameron's project of acquiring for photography the prestige accorded to painting was doomed to failure
to defend Cameron's masterpiece The Passing of Arthur against its detractors by showing that it transcends the homely details of its setting

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This isn’t the purpose of the passage. The author spends little time discussing Cameron’s development, and *The Passing of Arthur* is included as an example of one aspect of her work, **not** as a masterpiece.

This is the best choice. The author argues that there is a discrepancy between Cameron’s **aims** and the **results** she achieved. Her aims were to portray mythical scenes; her results were photographs of costumed, human actors. The author argues that the art produced was not a failure, but rather that this discrepancy enhanced the intrigue of Cameron’s works and made them even more enduring.

This isn’t the main purpose of the passage. The passage doesn’t regard Cameron’s vision as “essentially theatrical”, but rather compares **some** aspects of her work to the theater. The passage also identifies the realities of the actors, not Cameron’s theatrical representations, as the strengths of the photos.

This isn’t the purpose of the passage. The passage is concerned with arguing for the artistic value of Cameron’s work, **not** explaining how her choice of medium might affect the prestige she could attain. The prestige of photography and painting isn’t compared in any detail.

This isn’t the primary purpose of the passage. The purpose of the passage is to make a broader point about the aesthetic value of Cameron’s collected works, of which *The Passing of Arthur* is just one example.

items.questionType: Identifying Main Points and Primary Purposes
items.displayType: Identifying Main Points and Primary Purposes

items.stimulusText:
Some critics of advertising have assumed that the creation of false needs in consumers is the principal mechanism underlying what these critics regard as its manipulative and hegemonic power. Central to this type of critique are the writings of political theorist Herbert Marcuse, who maintained that modern people succumb to oppression by believing themselves satisfied in spite of their living in an objectively unsatisfying world. This process occurs because in mass market culture the powerful psychological techniques of advertising create "needs" that are false and whose satisfaction thus contributes, not to the genuine well-being of consumers, but rather to the profit—and thereby the disproportionate power—of corporations.

Marcuse supposed that we all have certain real needs, both physical and psychological. Advertising appropriates these needs for its own purposes, forging psychological associations between them and consumer items, e.g., between sex and perfume, thereby creating a false "need" for these items. Since the quest for fulfillment is thus displaced from its true objects to consumer items, the implicit promises of advertisements are never really fulfilled and the consumer remains at some level unsatisfied.

Unfortunately, the distinction between real and false needs upon which this critique depends is extremely problematic. If Marcusians are right, we cannot, with any assurance, separate our real needs from the alleged false needs we feel as a result of the manipulation of advertisers. For, in order to do so, it would be necessary to eliminate forces of persuasion that are so prevalent in society that they have come to inform our instinctive judgments about things.

But, in fact, Marcusians make a major mistake in assuming that the majority of consumers who respond to advertising do not do so autonomously. Advertising techniques are unable to induce unwilling behavior in rational, informed adults, and regulations prohibit misinformation in advertising claims. Moreover, evidence suggests that most adults understand and recognize the techniques used and are not merely passive instruments. If there is a real need for emotional fulfillment, and if we can freely and authentically choose our means of obtaining it, then free, informed individuals may choose to obtain it through the purchase of commodities or even through the enjoyment occasionally provided by advertisements themselves. It is no doubt true that in many—perhaps even most—cases the use of an advertised product does not yield the precise sort of emotional dividend that advertisements seem to promise. This does not mean, however, that consumers do not freely and intentionally use the product as a means to another sort of fulfillment, or even that its genuine fulfillment of needs must be less than the advertisement suggests.
items.stemText: Which one of the following most accurately expresses the main point of the passage?

options.optionContent: Advertising has greater social value than Marcusians have supposed, because it is both an effective means of informing consumers and often an intrinsically entertaining medium of mass communication.

Even if, as Marcusians have argued, there is a theoretical difference between real and false needs, that difference is obscured in practice by the relationship of consumers to the forces of persuasion in profit-motivated, consumer-oriented societies.

Marcusian arguments regarding advertisers' creation of false needs are mistaken, because individuals are able to make autonomous decisions regarding their needs and are even able to use the elements of mass market culture to achieve genuine fulfillment.

Critics of advertising typically focus on the development of false needs in the consumer and do not fully consider the ability of people to make independent choices by distinguishing their own real needs from the apparent needs that advertising induces.

The problematic distinction that Marcusians have drawn between real and false needs provides an inadequate basis for their attacks on advertising, because the distinction overlooks consumers' physical and psychological needs.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This is too strong to be the main point of the passage. While the passage doesn’t condemn advertising like the Marcusians do, it certainly doesn’t regard advertising as an “effective means of informing consumers”, and instead notes that rational consumers know to be skeptical of advertisements.
This is too narrow to be the main point of the passage. The difference between real and false needs is only one element in a larger discussion about the plausibility of the Marcusian viewpoint.
This is the main point of the passage. The passage argues that Marcuse’s argument is wrong, because individuals can make their own decisions with regard to the pursuit of fulfillment.
This isn’t the main point of the passage. The main point of the passage is a critique of Marcuse’s argument in particular, not critics of advertising in general.
This is too narrow to be the main point of the passage. The difference between real and false needs is only one element in a larger discussion about the plausibility of the Marcusian viewpoint.

Some critics of advertising have assumed that the creation of false needs in consumers is the principal mechanism underlying what these critics regard as its manipulative and hegemonic power. Central to this type of critique are the writings of political theorist Herbert Marcuse, who maintained that modern people succumb to oppression by believing themselves satisfied in spite of their living in an objectively unsatisfying world. This process occurs because in mass market culture the powerful psychological techniques of advertising create "needs" that are false and whose satisfaction thus contributes, not to the genuine well-being of consumers, but rather to the profit—and thereby the disproportionate power—of corporations.

Marcuse supposed that we all have certain real needs, both physical and psychological. Advertising appropriates these needs for its own purposes, forging psychological associations between them and consumer items, e.g., between sex and perfume, thereby creating a false "need" for these items. Since the quest for fulfillment is thus displaced from its true objects to consumer items, the implicit promises of advertisements are never really fulfilled and the consumer remains at some level unsatisfied.

Unfortunately, the distinction between real and false needs upon which this critique depends is extremely problematic. If Marcusians are right, we cannot, with any assurance, separate our real needs from the alleged false needs we feel as a result of the manipulation of advertisers. For, in order to do so, it would be necessary to eliminate forces of persuasion that are so prevalent in society that they have come to inform our instinctive judgments about things.

But, in fact, Marcusians make a major mistake in assuming that the majority of consumers who respond to advertising do not do so autonomously. Advertising techniques are unable to induce unwilling behavior in rational, informed adults, and regulations prohibit misinformation in advertising claims. Moreover, evidence suggests that most adults understand and recognize the techniques used and are not merely passive instruments. If there is a real need for emotional fulfillment, and if we can freely and authentically choose our means of obtaining it, then free, informed individuals may choose to obtain it through the purchase of commodities or even through the enjoyment occasionally provided by advertisements themselves. It is no doubt true that in many—perhaps even most—cases the use of an advertised product does not yield the precise sort of emotional dividend that advertisements seem to promise. This does not mean, however, that consumers do not freely and intentionally use the product as a means to another sort of fulfillment, or even that its genuine fulfillment of needs must be less than the advertisement suggests.
items.stemText: The author states that Marcuse believed that advertisers

options.optionContent: base many of their manipulative strategies on psychological research findings
appeal to people's real needs in order to create false needs
are restricted to a degree by regulations prohibiting misinformation
exaggerate the consumer's need for independent decision-making
deny that the needs they create in people are less real than other needs

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This isn’t supported by the passage. The passage makes no mention of psychological research findings.

This is the best choice. The passage states that Marcuse believed advertisers appealed to real needs to create the false needs. Specifically, the passage noted that advertising forges “psychological associations between [real needs] and consumer items.”
This is a belief of the author but not of Marcuse. It is the author who brings up the claim that “regulations prohibit misinformation in advertising claims.”
This mischaracterizes Marcuse’s belief as it is portrayed in the passage. Marcuse believed that advertisers actually *obscured* consumers’ decision-making by introducing false needs.
This conflicts with the passage. Marcuse wouldn’t deny, but would **agree** that the needs advertisers create in people (i.e., “fake needs”) are less real than other needs.

items.stemText: The main function of the first paragraph is to

options.optionContent: summarize the political and economic context from which Marcusian critiques of advertising arise
outline the mechanisms by which false needs originate in mass market culture
evaluate the psychological processes by which the manipulative techniques of mass market advertising influence individuals
describe the prevailing views among contemporary critics of advertising and categorize Marcuse's theories in relation to those views
describe Marcusian views regarding mass market manipulation and indicate their role in certain criticisms of advertising

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This mischaracterizes the purpose of the paragraph. The “political and economic context” of Marcusian critique are not summarized in the first paragraph (or anywhere else in the passage).
This is too narrow to be the purpose of the first paragraph. The first paragraph doesn’t mention any mechanisms by which false needs originate.
This isn’t the purpose of the first paragraph. The first paragraph doesn’t **evaluate** psychological processes (or anything else), but rather gives a **description** of Marcusian views.
This isn’t the purpose of the first paragraph. The first paragraph doesn’t describe any critical views *except* Marcuse’s.

This is the purpose of the first paragraph. First, the paragraph contextualizes Marcuse’s views as being “central” to critiques of advertising. Then it provides a description of Marcuse’s views regarding the “oppression” of “modern people” because of the false needs created by advertising (mass market manipulation).

items.stemText: Which one of the following is a claim that the author attributes to Marcuse?

options.optionContent: In modern society, advertising helps lead people to think that they are satisfied.
Modern societies differ from earlier societies in that they fail to satisfy basic physical needs.
It is impossible to draw any meaningful distinction between real and false psychological needs in modern society.
Advertising in modern society has sometimes become a tool of oppression working to the benefit of totalitarian political systems.
Advertising exploits basic human needs by deriving from them certain secondary needs which, though they become real needs, subtly work to the detriment of consumers.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This is the best choice. In explaining Marcuse’s critique of advertising, the author attributes this claim to him, saying “modern people succumb to oppression by believing themselves satisfied” due to the fulfillment of the false needs of advertising.

This isn’t something the author attributes to Marcuse. The author doesn’t provide any information about what Marcuse might have thought about earlier societies, or whether modern societies satisfy basic physical needs.

This conflicts with the ideas that the author attributes to Marcuse. According to the passage, Marcuse *does* draw a meaningful distinction between real and false needs as the basis for his critique of advertising.
This isn’t something the author attributes to Marcuse.  Totalitarian political systems aren’t mentioned in the passage.

This isn’t something the author attributes to Marcuse. The passage doesn’t discuss “secondary needs” but rather false needs, which never “become real needs”. When false needs are satisfied, they still leave consumers unfulfilled, because real needs continue to go unsatisfied.

items.stemText: By the term "forces of persuasion" (last sentence of the third paragraph), the author most probably refers to

options.optionContent: intentionally dishonest claims that some theorists argue are common in advertising
innate, instinctual drives that some theorists say are fundamental to human behavior
emotional pressures that some theorists claim are exerted over individuals by society as a whole
subtle practices of social indoctrination that some theorists say are sponsored by the state
manipulative influences that some theorists say go unrecognized by those affected by them

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This isn’t what “forces of persuasion” means in context. This choice might be tempting, because it refers to external influences (in advertising). But forces of persuasion don’t have to be “intentionally dishonest”. This choice is too strong to be correct.

This isn’t what “forces of persuasion” means in context. The theorists described in the passage focus on the *external* motivations of advertising (which is what “forces of persuasion” refers to), **not** the *internal* drives of human nature.
This isn’t what “forces of persuasion” means in context. “Emotional pressures” aren’t mentioned in the passage, which focused on physical and psychological needs.
This isn’t what “forces of persuasion” means in context. The passage doesn’t discuss ways in which the state could be involved in indoctrination.

This is a good definition for “forces of persuasion” as it’s used in the passage. In context, “forces of persuasion” are said to “inform our instinctive judgments about things.” So, we can define “forces of persuasion” as hidden, manipulative influences that affect our thinking without us knowing it.

items.stemText: Which one of the following sentences would most logically complete the passage?

options.optionContent: Therefore, while in principle there might be grounds for holding that advertising is detrimental to society, the Marcusian critique does not provide such grounds.
Therefore, although Marcusian claims about advertising are rationally justified, the mistake of many recent critics of advertising is in their use of these claims for political gain.
Therefore, any shift in basic assumptions required to correct the abuses of advertising will require a change in the perception of human nature held by corporate leaders.
Therefore, while emphasizing only detrimental social aspects of advertising, Marcusians have failed to consider that such aspects are clearly outweighed by numerous social benefits.

Therefore, the Marcusian critique of advertising is mistaken except in its claim that advertisers exert economic power over those few people who are unable or unwilling to distinguish real from false needs.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This is the best choice to complete the passage. The passage concludes that the Marcusian critique isn’t sufficient for proving that advertising is detrimental to society. The passage doesn’t argue conclusively whether advertising is detrimental to society.
This statement couldn’t complete the passage. The passage doesn’t view Marcusian claims as “rationally justified”, and it makes no mention of critiques using Marcusian claims for political gain.
This statement couldn’t complete the passage. The passage doesn’t regard advertising as abusive, and wouldn’t recommend a change “to correct the abuses of advertising”.
This statement couldn’t complete the passage. Even though the passage argues against the Marcusians’ claims, it never suggests that the positives of advertising *outweigh* the negatives.
This statement couldn’t complete the passage. The passage doesn’t discuss the set of people who are unable to distinguish real from false needs.

items.stimulusText:
Passage A

There are two principles that are fundamental to a theory of justice regarding property. The principle of justice in acquisition specifies the conditions under which someone can legitimately come to own something that was previously not owned by anyone. The principle of justice in transfer specifies the conditions under which the transfer of property from one person to another is justified.

Given such principles, if the world were wholly just, the following definition would exhaustively cover the subject of justice regarding property:

1. A person who acquires property in accordance with the principle of justice in acquisition is entitled to that property.

2. A person who acquires property in accordance with the principle of justice in transfer, from someone else who is entitled to the property, is entitled to the property.

3. No one is entitled to any property except by (repeated) applications of 1 and 2.

However, not all actual situations are generated in accordance with the principles of justice in acquisition and justice in transfer. Some people steal from others or defraud them, for example. The existence of past injustice raises the issue of the rectification of injustice. If past injustice has shaped present ownership in various ways, what, if anything, ought to be done to rectify that injustice? A principle of rectification would use historical information about previous situations and injustices done in them, and information about the actual course of events that flowed from these injustices, to produce a description of the property ownership that should have resulted. Actual ownership of property must then be brought into conformity with this description.

Passage B

In 1790, the United States Congress passed the Indian Nonintercourse Act, which requires that all transfers of lands from Native Americans to others be approved by the federal government. The law has not been changed in any relevant respect, and it remains in effect today. Its purpose is clear. It was meant to guarantee security to Native Americans against fraudulent acquisition by others of the Native Americans' land holdings. Several suits have been initiated by Native American tribes for recovery of lands held by them when the Nonintercourse Act took effect.

One natural (one might almost say obvious) way of reasoning about Native American claims to land in North America is this: Native Americans were the first human occupants of this land. Before the European invasion of North America, the land belonged to them. In the course of that invasion and its aftermath, the land was illicitly taken from them. The current owners lack a well-founded right to the land, which now lies illicitly in their hands. Ideally, the land should be restored to its rightful owners. This may be impractical; compromises might have to be made. But the original wrong can most easily be righted by returning the land to them—or by returning it wherever that is feasible.
items.stemText: Which one of the following most accurately describes the main purpose for which passage A was written and the main purpose for which passage B was written?

options.optionContent:
Passage A: to propose a solution to a moral problem

Passage B: to criticize a proposed solution to a moral problem

Passage A: to sketch a general outline of a branch of moral theory

Passage B: to give a particular moral analysis of a real case

Passage A: to spell out the details of two fundamental principles

Passage B: to examine a case that exemplifies a moral ideal

Passage A: to argue for a particular moral ideal

Passage B: to question the assumptions of a moral theory

Passage A: to advocate the use of certain moral principles

Passage B: to provide a counterexample to some widely held moral principles

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This doesn’t describe the purposes of the passages. Passage A doesn’t propose a solution to a moral problem; it sketches out a theory of justice regarding property. Passage B doesn’t *criticize* a proposed solution to a moral problem; it analyzes a case of a moral problem.

This is the best choice. Passage A sketches an outline of the a branch of moral theory, specifically a theory of justice regarding property. Passage B gives a moral analysis of the case of the theft of Native American lands.
This doesn’t describe the purposes of the passages. Passage B examines a case that *conflicts* with the moral ideals of property ownership.

This doesn’t describe the purposes of the passages. Passage A doesn’t argue for a moral ideal; it provides a rough outline of a part of a moral theory. Passage B doesn’t question the assumptions of a theory; it analyzes the morality of a particular case.

This doesn’t describe the purposes of the passages. Passage A doesn’t advocate for certain moral principles; it provides a rough outline of a part of a moral theory. Passage B isn’t a counterexample to any widely held moral principles; it's a moral analysis of a particular case.

items.stemText: Both passages explicitly mention which one of the following?

options.optionContent: transfer of property from one owner to another
a legal basis for recovery of property
entitlement to property in a wholly just world
practicability of rectification of past injustice
injustice committed as part of an invasion

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: Both passages explicitly mention this topic. Passage A mentions it with regard to the “principle of justice in transfer” of property. Passage B mentions it with the example of the transfer of Native American land (its usurpation by invading Europeans) and later with the suggestion that the land be returned to the Native Americans.

This isn’t explicitly mentioned in both passages. Passage A outline a *moral* basis for recovery of property, not a *legal* basis. Passage B mentions a legal basis for *protection* of property (the Indian Nonintercourse Act) and a *moral* basis for recovery of property (return of Native American lands), but never a legal basis for the recovery of property.
This isn’t explicitly mentioned in both passages. Passage A does explicitly mention the entitlement to property in a wholly just world, but passage B doesn’t.
This isn’t explicitly mentioned in both passages. Passage A mentions the rectification of past injustice, but *doesn’t* mention its practicability.
This isn’t explicitly mentioned in both passages. Passage A doesn’t explicitly mention injustice committed as part of an invasion.

items.stemText: Which one of the following is true of the relationship between passage A and the second paragraph of passage B?

options.optionContent: The second paragraph of passage B attempts to develop a broader version of the theory presented in passage A.
The second paragraph of passage B purports to state facts that bolster the argument made in passage A.
The argument in the second paragraph of passage B is structurally parallel to the argument in passage A, but the subject matter of the two is different.
Passage A presents a theory that tends to support the argument presented in the second paragraph of passage B.
The second paragraph of passage B attempts to undermine the theory presented in passage A.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This doesn’t describe the relationship. The second paragraph of passage B is a *particular example*, not a broader version.
This doesn’t describe the relationship. The example in passage B *relies on* the argument in passage A; it doesn’t support it.

This doesn’t describe the relationship. The second paragraph of passage B is an example that relies on the reasoning in passage A, not parallelism with different subject matter. Passage A is general, and applies its theories to no specific subject matter.

This is the best choice. The second paragraph of passage B is an argument for particular example which is **an application of** the theory in passage A. More concretely, the second paragraph of passage B argues that land should be returned to the Native Americans, and it uses reasoning about justice regarding property that is supported by the theory introduced in passage A.
This doesn’t describe the relationship. Far from attempting to undermine the theory of passage A, the second paragraph of passage B relies on the reasoning in passage A.

items.stemText: Based on what can be inferred from their titles, the relationship between which one of the following pairs of documents is most analogous to the relationship between passage A and passage B?

options.optionContent:
"Card Counting for Everyone: A Can't-Lose System for Beating the Dealer"

"The Evils of Gambling"

"Mayor McConnell Is Unfit to Serve"

"Why Mayor McConnell Should be Reelected"

"Pruning Fruit Trees: A Guide for the Novice"

"Easy Recipes for Beginning Cooks"

"Notable Failures of the STORM Weather Forecasting Model"

"Meteorologists' Best Tool Yet: The STORM Forecasting Model"

"Fundamentals of Building Construction and Repair"

"Engineering Report: The Repairs Needed by the Thales Building"

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This isn’t analogous to the relationship between the passages. The first title sounds like a how-to guide on a subject and the second title sounds like a moral condemnation of that subject (which isn’t at all the relationship between the passages).

This isn’t analogous to the relationship between the passages. The first title sounds like an argument **against** someone and the second title sounds like an argument **for** someone. But passage A and passage B don’t contradict one another.
This isn’t analogous to the relationship between the passages. These titles seem to be introductions to two different topics. Passage A and passage B both discuss the same topic: property rights.
This isn’t analogous to the relationship between the passages. The first title sounds like a study of the failures of a model, and the second title sounds like a study of the successes of that model.

This is analogous to the relationship between the passages. The first title sounds like an introduction to a subject, and the second title sounds like a case study of that subject. Likewise, passage A is a primer on a theory of justice, and passage B is a case study in how that theory of justice is applied.

items.questionType: Applying the Argument to New Contexts
items.displayType: Applying the Argument to New Contexts

items.stimulusText:
Passage A

There are two principles that are fundamental to a theory of justice regarding property. The principle of justice in acquisition specifies the conditions under which someone can legitimately come to own something that was previously not owned by anyone. The principle of justice in transfer specifies the conditions under which the transfer of property from one person to another is justified.

Given such principles, if the world were wholly just, the following definition would exhaustively cover the subject of justice regarding property:

1. A person who acquires property in accordance with the principle of justice in acquisition is entitled to that property.

2. A person who acquires property in accordance with the principle of justice in transfer, from someone else who is entitled to the property, is entitled to the property.

3. No one is entitled to any property except by (repeated) applications of 1 and 2.

However, not all actual situations are generated in accordance with the principles of justice in acquisition and justice in transfer. Some people steal from others or defraud them, for example. The existence of past injustice raises the issue of the rectification of injustice. If past injustice has shaped present ownership in various ways, what, if anything, ought to be done to rectify that injustice? A principle of rectification would use historical information about previous situations and injustices done in them, and information about the actual course of events that flowed from these injustices, to produce a description of the property ownership that should have resulted. Actual ownership of property must then be brought into conformity with this description.

Passage B

In 1790, the United States Congress passed the Indian Nonintercourse Act, which requires that all transfers of lands from Native Americans to others be approved by the federal government. The law has not been changed in any relevant respect, and it remains in effect today. Its purpose is clear. It was meant to guarantee security to Native Americans against fraudulent acquisition by others of the Native Americans' land holdings. Several suits have been initiated by Native American tribes for recovery of lands held by them when the Nonintercourse Act took effect.

One natural (one might almost say obvious) way of reasoning about Native American claims to land in North America is this: Native Americans were the first human occupants of this land. Before the European invasion of North America, the land belonged to them. In the course of that invasion and its aftermath, the land was illicitly taken from them. The current owners lack a well-founded right to the land, which now lies illicitly in their hands. Ideally, the land should be restored to its rightful owners. This may be impractical; compromises might have to be made. But the original wrong can most easily be righted by returning the land to them—or by returning it wherever that is feasible.
items.stemText: The author of passage A would be most likely to characterize the purpose of the Indian Nonintercourse Act as which one of the following?

options.optionContent: legitimization of actual property holdings during the eighteenth century
clarification of existing laws regarding transfer of property
assurance of conformity to the principle of justice in acquisition
prevention of violations of the principle of justice in transfer
implementation of a principle of rectification

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: We can’t infer that the author of passage A would agree with this. The Indian Nonintercourse Act *protects* the land of Native Americans by *delegitimizing* the property holdings of some Europeans in the eighteenth century, especially in the view of the author of passage A, who believes in “rectification of injustice”.
We can’t infer that the author of passage A would agree with this. Passage A doesn’t say whether the author has any knowledge of laws *before* the Indian Nonintercourse Act.

We can infer that the author of passage A would *disagree* with this idea. The Indian Nonintercourse Act is concerned with the *transfer* of land from Native Americans to Europeans, so, if anything, it would assure conformity to the principle of justice in *transfer*.

We can infer that the author of passage A would agree with this idea. The purpose of the Indian Nonintercourse Act, as described in the passage, was to protect Native Americans from the fraudulent seizure of their land. This is a violation of the principle of justice in transfer (as defined by passage A) because it concerns property changing ownership.

We can infer that the author of passage A *wouldn’t* agree with this. The Indian Nonintercourse Act (rather than attempt to *rectify* past injustices) seeks to *protect* Native American lands *before* they are usurped. Therefore, the author of passage A would describe the Indian Nonintercourse Act as a implementation of the principle of justice in transfer.

Passage B

The law has not been changed in any relevant respect, and it remains in effect today. Its purpose is clear. It was meant to guarantee security to Native Americans against fraudulent acquisition by others of the Native Americans' land holdings. One natural (one might almost say obvious) way of reasoning about Native American claims to land in North America is this: Native Americans were the first human occupants of this land. Before the European invasion of North America, the land belonged to them. In the course of that invasion and its aftermath, the land was illicitly taken from them. The current owners lack a well-founded right to the land, which now lies illicitly in their hands. Ideally, the land should be restored to its rightful owners. This may be impractical; compromises might have to be made. But the original wrong can most easily be righted by returning the land to them—or by returning it wherever that is feasible.
items.stemText: Which one of the following most accurately describes the difference in approach taken by passage A as compared to passage B?

options.optionContent: Passage A espouses a general view without providing details, while passage B sketches an argument that it does not necessarily endorse.
Passage A argues for the superiority of one view over competing views, while passage B considers only a single view.
Passage A invokes commonly held principles to support a policy recommendation, while passage B relies on the views of established authorities to support its claims.
Passage A briefly states a view and then provides an argument for it, while passage B provides a detailed statement of a view but no argument.
Passage A provides an argument in support of a view, while passage B attempts to undermine a view.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This is the best choice. Passage A gives us an introduction to a theory of justice regarding property. It doesn’t provide details on the principles it lists. Passage B sketches an argument about why land should be returned to Native Americans. It describes this argument as “natural”, but it never explicitly endorses the position.
This mischaracterizes the approach of passage A. Only one theory is presented in passage A, but the passage **doesn’t** argue for the superiority of that theory over competing theories.

This mischaracterizes the approaches of the passages. Passage A invokes principles, but it isn’t clear whether those principles are “commonly held”. Passage B doesn’t appeal to the views of any “established authorities”.
This mischaracterizes the approaches of the passages. Passage A doesn’t provide an argument for the theory it presents. Passage B **does** include an argument.

This mischaracterizes the approaches of the passages. Passage A presents a theory but **doesn’t** provide an argument to support that theory. Passage B doesn’t *undermine* a view; it simply explains one view.
