sections.directions: Directions: Each question in this section is based on the reasoning presented in a brief passage. In answering the questions, you should not make assumptions that are by commonsense standards implausible, superfluous, or incompatible with the passage. For some questions, more than one of the choices could conceivably answer the question. However, you are to choose the best answer; that is, choose the response that most accurately and completely answers the question.

items.stimulusText: Editorial: The city has chosen a contractor to upgrade the heating systems in public buildings. Only 40 percent of the technicians employed by this contractor are certified by the Heating Technicians Association. So the city selected a contractor 60 percent of whose technicians are unqualified, which is an outrage.
items.stemText: Which one of the following is an assumption required by the argument in the editorial?

options.optionContent: Certified technicians receive higher pay than uncertified technicians.
There are no contractors with fewer than 40 percent of their technicians certified.
Technicians who lack certification are not qualified technicians.
Qualified technicians installed the heating systems to be upgraded.
The contractor hired by the city has personal ties to city officials.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This comparison isn’t necessary for the editorial to work. The argument never addresses pay, but rather qualifications.
This isn’t necessary for the editorial to work. The argument is focused on *one* particular contractor, and what other contractors do isn’t relevant.

This is an assumption required by the editorial’s argument, which essentially equates *not certified* with *unqualified*. To test whether (C) *has* to be true, suppose that it’s false: what if technicians who lack certification *are* qualified technicians? In that case, the editorial’s argument would fall apart because it wouldn’t necessarily be true that 60% of the contractor’s technicians are unqualified.

This isn’t necessary for the editorial to work, because it doesn’t matter who installed the heating systems. The editorial’s author is outraged by the contractor’s seemingly “unqualified” technicians, based on their lack of certification. Whether qualified or unqualified technicians *actually* installed the heating systems doesn’t affect that connection.

This isn’t necessary for the argument to work, because personal ties aren’t relevant. It could help explain *why* the contractor was hired to begin with, but it doesn’t affect whether the technicians are either qualified or unqualified.

items.stimulusText: Jeneta: Increasingly, I've noticed that when a salesperson thanks a customer for making a purchase, the customer also says "Thank you" instead of saying "You're welcome." I've even started doing that myself. But when a friend thanks a friend for a favor, the response is always "You're welcome."
items.stemText: Which one of the following, if true, most helps to explain the discrepancy that Jeneta observes in people's responses?

options.optionContent: Customers regard themselves as doing salespeople a favor by buying from them as opposed to someone else.
Salespeople are often instructed by their employers to thank customers, whereas customers are free to say what they want.
Salespeople do not regard customers who buy from them as doing them a favor.
The way that people respond to being thanked is generally determined by habit rather than by conscious decision.
In a commercial transaction, as opposed to a favor, the customer feels that the benefits are mutual.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This actually *deepens* the mystery. It makes the customer/salesperson transaction interaction even more similar to the friend/friend favor interaction, which makes it even more puzzling that the responses to each situation are so different. If (A) is true, then we would expect the customers to respond, “You’re welcome” when the salesperson thanks them—not “Thank you”.

This doesn’t help explain the discrepancy. It helps explain why salespeople say, “Thank you” to begin with, but it doesn’t address the difference between the customer/salesperson transaction interaction and the friend/friend favor interaction.
This doesn’t help explain the discrepancy. The fact that salespeople say “Thank you” suggests that they *do* regard customers as doing them a favor.

This doesn’t help explain the discrepancy. Whether responses are determined by habit or by conscious decision, we still see a significant difference between how a customer responds and how a friend responds. (D) doesn’t explain why that difference exists.

This helps to explain the discrepancy between a customer’s response and a friend’s response. If (E) is true, then there’s a difference between commercial transactions and favors—and if the customer feels that the benefits are mutual in a commercial transaction, then it would be reasonable for the customer to thank the other party for the benefit received.

items.stimulusText: Some video game makers have sold the movie rights for popular games. However, this move is rarely good from a business perspective. After all, StarQuanta sold the movie rights to its popular game Nostroma, but the poorly made film adaptation of the game was hated by critics and the public alike. Subsequent versions of the Nostroma video game, although better than the original, sold poorly.
items.stemText: The reasoning in the argument is most vulnerable to criticism in that the argument

options.optionContent: draws a general conclusion on the basis of just one individual case
infers that a product will be disliked by the public merely from the claim that the product was disliked by critics
restates as a conclusion a claim earlier presented as evidence for that conclusion
takes for granted that products with similar content that are in different media will be of roughly equal popularity
treats a requirement for a product to be popular as something that ensures that a product will be popular

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This describes a flaw in the argument. The arguer concludes that selling the movie rights for popular games is “rarely good from a business perspective.” That’s a pretty general statement. However, the arguer supports this generalization with only one specific instance—that isn’t enough to demonstrate the conclusion, since we can’t tell if the *Nostroma* example is representative of other instances.

This doesn’t describe a flaw in the argument. The arguer doesn’t *infer* anything about the public’s dislike, but rather explicitly states that both the public and critics disliked the film adaptation.
This doesn’t describe a flaw in the argument, which never restates any of its claims.
This doesn’t describe a flaw in the argument. The arguer concludes that popular games *don’t* become popular movies, which conflicts with the reasoning of (D).
This doesn’t describe a flaw in the argument, which doesn’t say what is required for—or ensures—popularity.

items.stimulusText: Principle: The executive in a given company whose compensation package is determined by advice of an external consultant is likely to be overcompensated if the consultant also has business interests with the company the executive manages.
items.stemText: Which one of the following judgments conforms most closely to the principle stated above?

options.optionContent: The president of the Troskco Corporation is definitely overpaid, since he receives in salary and benefits almost 40 times more than the average employee of Troskco receives.
The president of the Troskco Corporation is probably overpaid, since his total annual compensation package was determined five years ago, when the company's profits were at an all-time high.

The president of the Troskco Corporation is probably not overpaid, since his total compensation package was determined by the Troskco board of directors without retaining the services of an external compensation consultant.

The president of Troskco Corporation is probably overpaid, since the Troskco board of directors determined his compensation by following the advice of an external consultant who has many other contracts with Troskco.
The president of Troskco Corporation is definitely not overpaid, since the external consultant the board of directors retained to advise on executive salaries has no other contracts with Troskco.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: The conclusion is that this executive is "definitely" overpaid, which is a stronger conclusion than the principle would allow to be drawn, so this answer is incorrect.
The premise of this answer has nothing to do with consultants, so it's incorrect.
The principle in the stimulus allows a conclusion to be drawn that an executive is "likely to be overcompensated," not that they are probably not overpaid, so this answer is incorrect.

This answer concludes that an executive is "probably overpaid" based on the salary being set by a consultant with "many other contracts" with the same company the executive works for—and other contracts certainly count as business interests. This answer aligns with the details of the principle in the stimulus and reaches a conclusion that can be justified by it, so it's the correct answer.
This answer's conclusion is that someone is definitely not overpaid—stronger and the opposite of the conclusion that can be drawn based on the principle in the stimulus.

items.stimulusText: Science writer: Lemaître argued that the universe began with the explosion of a "primeval atom," a singular point of infinite gravity in space and time. If this is correct, our current observations should reveal galaxies accelerating away from one another. This is precisely what we observe. Yet because there is another theory—the oscillating universe theory—that makes exactly this same prediction, Lemaître's theory must be considered inadequate.
items.stemText: Which one of the following most accurately describes a flaw in the science writer's reasoning?

options.optionContent: The conclusion is derived partly from assertions attributed to a purported expert whose credibility is not established.
The conclusion is based on a shift in meaning of a key term from one part of the argument to another part.
The science writer takes for granted the existence of a causal connection between observed phenomena.
The science writer fails to see that one theory's correctly predicting observed data cannot itself constitute evidence against an alternative theory that also does this.
The science writer presumes, without providing justification, that there are only two possible explanations for the phenomena in question.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: The conclusion is that Lemaitre's theory is inadequate, so it's not appealing to his expertise. And the alternative theory isn't attributed to anyone, so this argument isn't making an inappropriate appeal to an expert.
The conclusion is about Lemaitre's theory and inadequacy—the theory is still referring to the same theory, and the argument never before discusses inadequacy, so this answer is incorrect.
The argument never assumes causality—it simply raises a prediction that flows from a theory that happens to be true.

This answer choice highlights that two competing theories making the same prediction don't provide evidence against each other. While two theories making the same prediction means that evidence supporting that prediction can't help determine between the two theories which is correct, it doesn't mean that either theory is inadequate, either.

The stimulus doesn't get into the explanations (or their number) for the phenomenon in question (the acceleration of the galaxies)—for all we know, the oscillating universe theory could also be based on an explosion that formed the universe. And just because the Writer only raises two theories doesn't mean that there aren't others out there.

items.stimulusText: Critic: The criticism of the popular film comedy Quirks for not being realistic is misguided. It is certainly true that the characters are too stylized to be real people. That could be problematic, but in this case the resulting film is funny. And that is the important thing for a comedy.
items.stemText: Which one of the following principles, if valid, most helps to justify the reasoning in the critic's argument?

options.optionContent: Films should be judged on how well they accurately capture the world.
Films are successful as long as they are popular.
Film comedies should find their humor in their stylistic portrayals.
Films are successful if they succeed within their genre.
Films should try to stay entirely within a single genre.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: If this principle were true, then the criticism of Quirks for having unrealistic characters—i.e., not accurately capturing the world—would be valid, not misguided.

While the Critic does note that Quirks is popular, she doesn't use that to support the conclusion that criticism of it for not being realistic is misguided. Rather, it's the success at the characters in being funny that justifies the conclusion.
The argument isn't about where comedies should find their comedy, but rather whether a comedy that has found its comedy succeeds despite being unrealistic.

The Critic concludes that criticism of Quirks is misguided because the unrealistic characters are funny, which is what's important in a comedy. In other words, Quirks succeeds as a comedy, which, according to this answer, means it succeeds as a film, justifying the conclusion in the stimulus that criticism of it for being unrealistic is misguided. This answer justifies the argument and is thus correct.
The argument isn't about what films should do, but rather how to determine if a film is successful in doing whatever it sets out to do—e.g., is a comedy funny?

items.stimulusText: Party X has recently been accused by its opposition, Party Y, of accepting international campaign contributions, which is illegal. Such accusations are, however, ill founded. Three years ago, Party Y itself was involved in a scandal in which it was discovered that its national committee seriously violated campaign laws.
items.stemText: Which one of the following contains flawed reasoning most similar to the flawed reasoning in the argument above?

options.optionContent: The plaintiff accuses the defendant of violating campaign laws, but the accusations are ill founded. While the defendant's actions may violate certain laws, they are not immoral, because the laws in question are unjust.
The plaintiff accuses the defendant of violating campaign laws, but these accusations show the plaintiff to be hypocritical, because the plaintiff has engaged in similar conduct.

The plaintiff accuses the defendant of violating campaign laws, and, in the past, courts have declared such violations illegal. Nevertheless, because the plaintiff recently engaged in actions that were similar to those of the defendant, the plaintiff's accusations are ill founded.

The plaintiff accuses the defendant of violating campaign laws, but these accusations are ill founded. They are clearly an attempt to stir up controversy, because they were made just two weeks before the election.

The plaintiff accuses the defendant of voting only for campaign laws that would favor the defendant's party. This accusation is ill founded, however, because it attacks the defendant's motivations instead of addressing the arguments the defendant has put forth justifying these votes.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This argument doesn’t contain flawed reasoning similar to the passage’s flawed reasoning. The passage dismisses Party Y’s accusations on the basis that Party Y (the accuser) was guilty of the same bad behavior. This choice focuses only on the defendant (the accused), and not the accuser.

This argument doesn’t contain flawed reasoning similar to the passage’s flawed reasoning. In fact, this argument isn’t flawed at all, because it *is* true that the plaintiff is hypocritical for having engaged in the same conduct that the plaintiff is accusing the defendant of. The passage, on the other hand, doesn’t call the accuser hypocritical; instead, it dismisses the accuser’s accusations outright.

This argument’s reasoning is flawed in a way that’s similar to how the passage’s reasoning is flawed. The passage dismisses the accuser’s (Party Y’s) accusations based on the fact that the accuser had also committed the same bad behavior. Similarly, (C) dismisses the plaintiff’s accusations on the sole grounds that the plaintiff had recently engaged in the same bad behavior.

This argument doesn’t contain flawed reasoning similar to the passage’s flawed reasoning. The passage dismisses Party Y’s accusations on the basis that Party Y (the accuser) was guilty of the same bad behavior. This choice, in contrast, questions the motives for and timing of the accusations as a basis for dismissing those accusations.

This argument doesn’t contain flawed reasoning similar to the passage’s flawed reasoning. The passage dismisses Party Y’s accusations on the basis that Party Y (the accuser) was guilty of the same bad behavior. This choice focuses instead on the nature of the accusation itself (and not the behavior of the accuser).

items.stimulusText: Biologist: Marine animals known as box jellyfish have eyes with well-formed lenses capable of producing sharp images that reveal fine detail. But the box jellyfish's retinas are too far forward to receive a clear image, so these jellyfish can receive only a blurry image that reveals prominent features of objects but not fine detail. This example shows that eyes are adapted only to an animal's needs rather than to some abstract sense of how a good eye would be designed.
items.stemText: The argument requires assuming which one of the following?

options.optionContent: Box jellyfish are the only kind of jellyfish with retinas that do not focus clearly.
Box jellyfish have a need to detect prominent features of objects but not fine details.
Box jellyfish would benefit from having retinas that allowed their eyes to focus more sharply.
Box jellyfish developed from jellyfish whose retinas received clear images.
Box jellyfish use vision as their main means of detecting prey.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This isn’t something that the argument requires to be true. This argument is specifically about box jellyfish, so what’s true  about *other* kinds of jellyfish isn’t relevant.

This is necessary in order for the argument to work. To test it, try negating it: suppose that box jellyfish *don’t* have a need to detect prominent features of objects, and that they do need to detect  fine details. In that case, the argument would be severely weakened—the biologist would hardly be able to conclude that eyes are adapted “only to an animal’s *needs*” if the nature of box jellyfish’s eyes don’t serve a need.

This isn’t something that the argument requires to be true. The opposite needs to be true for the argument to work. The argument hinges on box jellyfish benefitting from seeing only prominent features, so seeing more sharply would actually *harm* them.
This isn’t something that the argument requires to be true. How eyes might have evolved isn’t relevant to what their purpose is *now*.

This isn’t something that the argument requires to be true, because how vision is used isn’t relevant. It’s too strong, in any case, to assume that box jellyfish use vision as their *main* means of detecting prey. If box jellyfish used smell as their main means and vision as a backup means, the argument would be unaffected.

items.stimulusText: Columnist: Research shows significant reductions in the number of people smoking, and especially in the number of first-time smokers in those countries that have imposed stringent restrictions on tobacco advertising. This provides substantial grounds for disputing tobacco companies' claims that advertising has no significant causal impact on the tendency to smoke.
items.stemText: Which one of the following, if true, most undermines the columnist's reasoning?

options.optionContent: People who smoke are unlikely to quit merely because they are no longer exposed to tobacco advertising.
Broadcast media tend to have stricter restrictions on tobacco advertising than do print media.
Restrictions on tobacco advertising are imposed only in countries where a negative attitude toward tobacco use is already widespread and increasing.
Most people who begin smoking during adolescence continue to smoke throughout their lives.
People who are largely unaffected by tobacco advertising tend to be unaffected by other kinds of advertising as well.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This doesn’t weaken the columnist’s reasoning, which concerns the *tendency* to smoke and focuses on the number of *first-time smokers* in countries with restricted tobacco advertising. So, information about people who *already* smoke doesn’t affect the argument.
This comparison doesn’t weaken the columnist’s reasoning. We aren’t concerned with how much more strict broadcast media are than print media—the argument concerns tobacco advertising *in general*.

This weakens the columnist’s reasoning, because it provides a possible *alternate* explanation for why there are significantly fewer first-time smokers in the countries with rigorous tobacco advertising restrictions. If (C) is true, then people were already disinclined to smoke *before* the restrictions on tobacco advertising were imposed, which would severely weaken the passage’s claim that advertising caused fewer people to start smoking.

Note: if you got the conclusion backwards and thought it was that advertising has *no* significant causal impact on the tendency to smoke, remember to read carefully and keep track of different points of view. It’s the *tobacco companies* who claim that there’s no causal impact, and the columnist *disputes* that claim.

This doesn’t weaken the columnist’s reasoning, which concerns the *tendency* to smoke and focuses on the number of *first-time smokers* in countries with restricted tobacco advertising. So, information about whether new smokers *continue* to smoke doesn’t affect the argument.
This doesn’t weaken the columnist’s reasoning, because other types of advertising (besides tobacco advertising) fall completely outside of the scope of this argument.

items.stimulusText: Actor: Bertolt Brecht's plays are not genuinely successful dramas. The roles in Brecht's plays express such incongruous motives and beliefs that audiences, as well as the actors playing the roles, invariably find it difficult, at best, to discern any of the characters' personalities. But, for a play to succeed as a drama, audiences must care what happens to at least some of its characters.
items.stemText: The conclusion of the actor's argument can be properly drawn if which one of the following is assumed?

options.optionContent: An audience that cannot readily discern a character's personality will not take any interest in that character.
A character's personality is determined primarily by the motives and beliefs of that character.
The extent to which a play succeeds as a drama is directly proportional to the extent to which the play's audiences care about its characters.
If the personalities of a play's characters are not readily discernible by the actors playing the roles, then those personalities are not readily discernible by the play's audience.
All plays that, unlike Brecht's plays, have characters with whom audiences empathize succeed as dramas.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This allows the actor’s conclusion to be properly drawn. The gap between the two pieces of evidence in the argument is specifically between an audience needing to care what happens to a play’s characters and the audience’s difficulty in discerning characters’ personalities. (A) explicitly ties these pieces together.

This doesn’t allow the actor’s conclusion to be properly drawn. There’s no link to show us why Brecht’s plays aren’t genuinely successful dramas; this only helps explain why an audience might find it difficult to discern a character’s personality—the actor tells us that Brecht’s characters show incongruous motives and beliefs.
This doesn’t allow the actor’s conclusion to be properly drawn. It only takes a piece of information we were already given (in the last sentence) and makes it more mathematically specific.

This doesn’t allow the actor’s conclusion to be properly drawn. (D) gives us a causal relationship between the actors’ difficulty in discerning characters and the audiences’ difficulty in discerning personalities, which doesn’t help us tie everything back to Brecht’s plays being unsuccessful dramas overall.

This doesn’t allow the actor’s conclusion to be properly drawn. We’re told in the last sentence that if a play succeeds as a drama, then audiences care what happens to at least some of the characters. (E) tells us what happens if audiences care about what happens to the characters, which isn’t helpful and simply reverses the actor’s last statement.

items.stimulusText: Municipal legislator: The mayor proposes that the city accept a lighting company's gift of several high-tech streetlights. Surely there would be no problem in accepting these despite some people's fear that the company wants to influence the city's decision regarding park lighting contracts. The only ulterior motive I can find is the company's desire to have its products seen by mayors who will visit the city for an upcoming convention. In any case, favoritism in city contracts is prevented by our competitive-bidding procedure.
items.stemText: Which one of the following most accurately expresses the main conclusion of the municipal legislator's argument?

options.optionContent: Some people's fear that the company wants to influence the city's decision regarding park lighting contracts is unfounded.
The mayor's proposal to accept the gift of streetlights should not be considered problematic.
It is not appropriate that any company should have the unique opportunity to display its products to mayors attending the upcoming convention.
The city's competitive-bidding procedure prevents favoritism in the dispensing of city contracts.
The lighting company's desire to display its products to visiting mayors is the real motivation behind the suggested gift of streetlights.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This is sometimes tempting to students, but it’s not the legislator’s *main* conclusion. The legislator *does* mention that some people fear that the company wants to influence the city’s decision regarding park lighting contracts, but this is only *part* of the main conclusion. The legislator dismisses this fear while making the more important claim that there should be no problem in accepting the lighting company’s gifts.

This is the legislator’s main conclusion. It’s an opinion that the legislator expresses; it’s supported *by* other statements in the passage; and it doesn’t itself support any other statements. The passage following this claim serves to answer the question, “Why isn’t it problematic to accept the gift?”

This isn’t the legislator’s main conclusion. The legislator never addresses a company’s *unique opportunity* to do anything; and, if we analyze (C), it could even conflict with the legislator’s opinion. The legislator is confident in the laws against favoritism, and that would suggest that the legislator would be okay with a company having a unique opportunity to display its products.

This isn’t the legislator’s main conclusion. They do say that “favoritism in city contracts is prevented by our competitive-bidding procedure”, but this is in service of a broader point, namely that the mayor’s proposal to accept the gift of the streetlights isn’t problematic.
This isn’t the legislator’s main conclusion. The legislator identifies this as the only *possible* ulterior motive, but never claims that it *is* the real motive.

items.stimulusText: The chairperson should not have released the Election Commission's report to the public, for the chairperson did not consult any other members of the commission about releasing the report before having it released.
items.stemText: The argument's conclusion can be properly inferred if which one of the following is assumed?

options.optionContent: It would have been permissible for the chairperson to release the commission's report to the public only if most other members of the commission had first given their consent.
All of the members of the commission had signed the report prior to its release.
The chairperson would not have been justified in releasing the commission's report if any members of the commission had serious reservations about the report's content.
The chairperson would have been justified in releasing the report only if each of the commission's members would have agreed to its being released had they been consulted.
Some members of the commission would have preferred that the report not be released to the public.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation:
This allows the argument’s conclusion to be properly inferred. To test it, try adding (A) to the passage’s premise; if, when combined, the two statements lead to a deduction that matches the passage’s conclusion, then (A) is a sufficient assumption.

* [Passage’s premise:] The chairperson didn’t consult any other members of the commission about releasing the report before having it released.
* [(A)’s premise:] And, it would have been permissible for the chairperson to released the commission’s report to the public *only if* most other members of the commission had first given their consent.

These two premises combined lead us to infer that the chairperson shouldn’t have released the report. There should have been consent from *most* of the other commission members, and the chairperson consulted *none* of the other commission members! 

Since this deduction matches the passage’s conclusion, we can confirm that (A) is a sufficient assumption.

This doesn’t allow the argument’s conclusion to be properly inferred. The arguer concludes that the chairperson *shouldn’t* have released the report. If anything, learning that all of the members had signed the report prior to its released almost *conflicts* with the passage’s evidence that none of the members were consulted before the report was released.

This doesn’t allow the argument’s conclusion to be properly inferred. The passage never addresses anything about commission members having serious reservations, but rather addresses the members being consulted at all.

This doesn’t allow the argument’s conclusion to be properly inferred. The passage isn’t concerned with whether the commission’s members *would have agreed* if consulted, but rather whether they had even been consulted at all. The possible outcome of the consultations isn’t addressed, and therefore isn’t relevant to the argument.

This doesn’t allow the argument’s conclusion to be properly inferred. It might strengthen the idea that the report shouldn’t have been released, but it doesn’t *guarantee* that the report shouldn’t have been released. It’s possible that just having one member consulted, even if that person disagrees, would be enough to justify the report’s release.

items.stimulusText: Reformer: A survey of police departments keeps track of the national crime rate, which is the annual number of crimes per 100,000 people. The survey shows no significant reduction in the crime rate in the past 20 years, but the percentage of the population in prison has increased substantially, and public expenditure on prisons has grown at an alarming rate. This demonstrates that putting more people in prison cannot help to reduce crime.
items.stemText: A flaw in the reformer's argument is that it

options.optionContent: infers without justification that because the national crime rate has increased, the number of crimes reported by each police department has increased
ignores the possibility that the crime rate would have significantly increased if it had not been for the greater rate of imprisonment
overlooks the possibility that the population has increased significantly over the past 20 years
presumes, without providing warrant, that alternative measures for reducing crime would be more effective than imprisonment
takes for granted that the number of prisoners must be proportional to the number of crimes committed

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This isn’t a flaw in the reformer’s argument. For one thing, the reformer never mentions that any crime rate has *increased*—only that there hasn’t been a significant *decrease*. For another, the issue of the number of crimes reported by *each* police department doesn’t factor into this argument, which addresses the national crime rate as a whole.

This is a flaw in the reformer’s argument. The reformer concludes that putting more people in prison has ***no*** effect on reducing the crime rate, due to the rather dismal conditions named in the evidence. However, that conclusion doesn’t follow, because it’s possible, as (B) states, that the crime rate could be *even worse* if fewer people had been imprisoned.

This isn’t a flaw in the reformer’s argument, though some students get distracted by (C). Note that the passage discusses the prison population in terms of *percentage*, and defines crime rate as the number of crimes per 100,000 people (which is also a rate)—that means that the actual population doesn’t matter. In other words, if a 10% crime rate moved to a 50% crime rate, we could say that the crime *rate* worsened, no matter what the actual number of people involved are.

This isn’t a flaw in the reformer’s argument, because the reformer never mentions alternative measures. The reformer simply claims that *imprisonment* cannot help reduce the crime rate. It’s possible that the reformer doesn’t believe that *any* measures could help reduce the crime rate.
This isn’t a flaw in the reformer’s argument. The reformer never addresses any kind of mathematical proportion between number of prisoners and number of crimes committed.

items.stimulusText:
Inez: Space-exploration programs pay for themselves many times over, since such programs result in technological advances with everyday, practical applications. Space exploration is more than the search for knowledge for its own sake; investment in space exploration is such a productive investment in developing widely useful technology that we can't afford not to invest in space exploration.

Winona: It is absurd to try to justify funding for space exploration merely by pointing out that such programs will lead to technological advances. If technology with practical applications is all that is desired, then it should be funded directly.
items.stemText: Winona responds to Inez by

options.optionContent: showing that there is no evidence that the outcome Inez anticipates will in fact be realized
suggesting that Inez has overlooked evidence that directly argues against the programs Inez supports
demonstrating that the pieces of evidence that Inez cites contradict each other
providing evidence that the beneficial effects that Inez desires can be achieved only at great expense
claiming that a goal that Inez mentions could be pursued without the programs Inez endorses

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: Winona doesn't question whether space research will lead to technological advancement, instead saying that if that's the goal it should be funded directly.
Winona doesn't raise evidence—she raises an argument around the logic behind Inez's argument.
Winona doesn't call out Inez's argument as contradictory but rather absurd.
Winona doesn't mention the expense, so this answer is out of scope.
This answer reflects Winona's argument that the goal Inez mentions—technological advances—could be achieved by funding them directly instead of indirectly through the space program.

items.stimulusText: Marketing consultant: Last year I predicted that LRG's latest advertising campaign would be unpopular with customers and ineffective in promoting new products. But LRG ignored my predictions and took the advice of a competing consultant. This season's sales figures show that sales are down and LRG's new products are selling especially poorly. Thus, the advertising campaign was ill conceived.
items.stemText: The marketing consultant's reasoning is most vulnerable to criticism on the grounds that

options.optionContent: it takes for granted that LRG's sales would not have been lower still in the absence of the competitor's advertising campaign
it fails to consider that economic factors unrelated to the advertising campaign may have caused LRG's low sales figures
it takes for granted that in LRG's industry, new products should outsell established products
it takes for granted that the higher sales of established products are due to effective advertising
it confuses a condition necessary for increasing product sales with a condition that will ensure increased sales

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This is sometimes tempting to students, but it doesn’t describe a flaw in the consultant’s argument. *If* the consultant were arguing that LRG should *never* have launched the campaign, *then* (A) would be applicable. But the consultant is simply assuming that the ad campaign—and nothing else—*caused* the poor sales.

This describes a flaw in the marketing consultant’s reasoning. The consultant takes a correlation—the campaign happening in roughly the same time period as the lower sales—and claims causation from it. But it’s just as possible that something *other* than the campaign could have led to the lower sales. So, the conclusion of causation doesn’t necessarily follow from the support of correlation.
This isn’t a flaw in the marketing consultant’s reasoning. The consultant doesn’t do what (C) describes—we never see any hint of a comparison between sales of new products and established products.
This isn’t a flaw in the marketing consultant’s reasoning. The consultant doesn’t address any potential reasons for higher sales of established products.

This isn’t a flaw in the marketing consultant’s reasoning, although it *is* a fairly common flaw elsewhere on the LSAT. There are no necessary or sufficient conditions to speak of in the consultant’s argument. (E) would be correct for a flawed argument such as, “The only way to increase product sales is to hire more marketers. So, since LRG just hired 50 more marketers, we should see increased product sales from them imminently.”

items.stimulusText: The top prize in architecture, the Pritzker Prize, is awarded for individual achievement, like Nobel Prizes for science. But architects are judged by their buildings, and buildings are the result of teamwork. As achievements, buildings are not like scientific discoveries, but like movies, which compete for awards for best picture. Thus, it would be better if the top prize in architecture were awarded to the best building rather than the best architect.
items.stemText: The argument proceeds by

options.optionContent: reaching a conclusion about the way something should be done in one field on the basis of comparisons with corresponding practices in other fields
making a distinction between two different types of objects in order to conclude that one has more inherent value than the other
pointing to similarities between two practices as a basis for concluding that criticisms of one practice can rightly be applied to the other
arguing that because two different fields are disanalogous, the characteristics of one field are not relevant to justifying a conclusion about the other
contending that an action is inappropriate by presenting an argument that a corresponding action in an analogous case is inappropriate

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: The argument reaches a conclusion about the way awards should ("would be better") be granted in architecture by comparing that field to how awards are granted in film (similar) and science (dissimilar). This answer highlights the argument's reliance on comparisons, so it's the correct answer.
There's no discussion or comparison of value, so this answer is out of scope.

There are two possibilities for what this answer choice is discussing. If the two similar practices are how prizes are awarded in science and architecture currently, the author doesn't have any criticism of how those science prizes are awarded. If the two similar practices are between making movies and making buildings, neither is criticized—instead, giving awards to the architect is criticized, which isn't the practice that's compared.

The two fields that are said to be disanalogous here are science and architecture. However, the argument doesn't conclude that the characteristics of science can't be used to justify a conclusion about architecture, but rather that the similarities between architecture and filmmaking provide a better model for awarding prizes.
The argument concludes that one action would be "better" than another, not that one is inappropriate.

items.stimulusText: If Suarez is not the most qualified of the candidates for sheriff, then Anderson is. Thus, if the most qualified candidate is elected and Suarez is not elected, then Anderson will be.
items.stemText: The reasoning in which one of the following is most similar to the reasoning in the argument above?

options.optionContent: If the excavation contract does not go to the lowest bidder, then it will go to Caldwell. So if Qiu gets the contract and Caldwell does not, then the contract will have been awarded to the lowest bidder.
If the lowest bidder on the sanitation contract is not Dillon, then it is Ramsey. So if the contract goes to the lowest bidder and it does not go to Dillon, then it will go to Ramsey.
If Kapshaw is not awarded the landscaping contract, then Johnson will be. So if the contract goes to the lowest bidder and it does not go to Johnson, then it will go to Kapshaw.

If Holihan did not submit the lowest bid on the maintenance contract, then neither did Easton. So if the contract goes to the lowest bidder and it does not go to Easton, then it will not go to Holihan either.

If Perez is not the lowest bidder on the catering contract, then Sullivan is. So if Sullivan does not get the contract and Perez does not get it either, then it will not be awarded to the lowest bidder.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This reasoning isn’t similar to the passage’s reasoning. We learn that the contract will go to either the lowest bidder or Caldwell. Then, Qiu is introduced in the conclusion. There’s nothing in the passage that corresponds to the new element of Qiu.

This reasoning is similar to the passage’s reasoning. In (B), either Dillon or Ramsey is the lowest bidder on the sanitation contract. So if the contract goes to the lowest bidder, and it’s not Dillon, then it has to be Ramsey.

We see similar reasoning in the passage. Instead of being the “lowest bidder”, it’s two people who could be the “most qualified”. Either Suarez or Anderson is the most qualified, so if the most qualified person is elected, and it’s not Suarez, then it has to be Anderson. Getting elected, in this analogy, is equivalent to the getting the contract.

This reasoning isn’t similar to the passage’s reasoning. We learn that the contract will go to either Kapshaw or Johnson. Then, “the lowest bidder” is introduced in the conclusion. There’s nothing in the passage that corresponds to the new element of “the lowest bidder”, since neither Kapshaw nor Johnson were assigned an attribute (such as “the most qualified”, as we see in the passage).

This reasoning isn’t similar to the passage’s reasoning, because it draws conclusions about what will *not* happen, which doesn’t give us any indication of what *will* happen. The passage, on the other hand, clearly states what *will* happen.

This reasoning isn’t similar to the passage’s reasoning. We learn that either Perez is *not* the lowest bidder, or Sullivan *is* the lowest bidder. The passage, on the other hand, states that either Suarez or Anderson *is* the most qualified candidate for sheriff. The choice to be made here isn’t similar to the choice in the passage.

items.stimulusText: Critic: An art historian argues that because fifteenth-century European paintings were generally more planimetric (that is, two-dimensional with no attempt at suggesting depth) than were sixteenth-century paintings, fifteenth-century painters had a greater mastery of painting than did sixteenth-century painters. However, this conclusion is wrong. Fifteenth-century European painters did not have a greater mastery of painting, for the degree to which a painting is planimetric is irrelevant to the painter's mastery.
items.stemText: The argument is flawed in that it

options.optionContent: rejects a position merely because the proponent of the position has other objectionable views
illicitly relies on two different meanings of the term "mastery"
takes a necessary condition for an argument's being inadequate to be a sufficient condition for an argument's being inadequate
bases its conclusion on two claims that contradict each other
rejects a position on the grounds that an inadequate argument has been made for it

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This doesn’t describe a flaw in the critic’s argument. The art historian (the proponent of the position being rejected) *doesn’t* have other objectionable views that we know of, so this isn’t what the critic is doing.
This doesn’t describe a flaw in the critic’s argument. The critic consistently uses the word “mastery” to mean something like expert skill.

This doesn’t describe a flaw in the critic’s argument. The critic doesn’t cite either a necessary or sufficient condition for an argument to be inadequate. There isn’t any concrete conditional logic in this argument, which is usually where we’d see (C)’s flaw exhibited.

This doesn’t describe a flaw in the critic’s argument, which contains no contradictory claims; rather, the critic rejects the art historian’s conclusion due to disagreeing with the art historian’s evidence.

This describes a flaw in the critic’s argument. The critic rejects the art historian’s conclusion because they reject the art historian’s evidence. 

Just because the critic doesn’t agree with the evidence, doesn’t mean that historian’s conclusion isn’t true. There could still be *other* reasons why 15th-century painters are better painters than 16th-century painters, even if *this* one reason doesn’t work.

To put this into a simpler context, one might argue, “It’s clear that the earth must revolve around the sun, because cats can fly.” Someone else *can’t* then logically counterargue that cats *can’t* fly so the earth must *not* revolve around the sun.

items.stimulusText: A carved flint object depicting a stylized human head with an open mouth was found in a Stone Age tomb in Ireland. Some archaeologists believe that the object was a weapon—the head of a warrior's mace—but it is too small for that purpose. Because of its size and the fact that an open mouth symbolizes speaking, the object was probably the head of a speaking staff, a communal object passed around a small assembly to indicate who has the right to speak.
items.stemText: Which one of the following, if true, would most weaken the argument?

options.optionContent: The tomb in which the object was found did not contain any other objects that might have been weapons.
Communal objects were normally passed from one generation to the next in Stone Age Ireland.
The object was carved with an artistry that was rare in Stone Age Ireland.
The tomb in which the object was found was that of a politically prominent person.
A speaking staff with a stone head is thought to symbolize a warrior's mace.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This doesn’t weaken the argument. We have no reason to believe or not believe that a tomb needs to contain multiple objects with the same functionality in order to support the identification of an object found in that tomb.

This information weakens the argument. The arguer rejects the possibility that the object could be a weapon and claims instead that the object is part of a speaking staff—a communal object. If (B) is true, then it would be *less* likely that the object is communal, because a communal object would probably not be buried in a tomb if communal objects were usually passed from one generation to the next.
This information doesn’t hurt the argument. How the object was carved doesn’t affect what the object was used for.
This information doesn’t weaken the argument, since we have no way of knowing whether politically prominent people are more or less likely to be buried with certain types of objects.

This information doesn’t weaken the argument. What an object *symbolizes* doesn’t change what that object is. For example, a paperweight might symbolize a planet, but it’s still a paperweight, and *not* a planet.

items.stimulusText: The advent of chemical fertilizers led the farmers in a certain region to abandon the practice of periodically growing a "green-manure" crop, such as alfalfa, in a field to rejuvenate its soil. As a result, the soil structure in a typical farm field in the region is poor. So to significantly improve the soil structure, farmers will need to abandon the use of chemical fertilizers.
items.stemText: The argument relies on the assumption that

options.optionContent: most, if not all, farmers in the region who abandon the use of chemical fertilizers will periodically grow alfalfa
applying chemical fertilizers to green-manure crops, such as alfalfa, has no positive effect on their growth
the most important factor influencing the soil quality of a farm field is soil structure
chemical fertilizers themselves have a destructive effect on the soil structure of farm fields
many, if not all, farmers in the region will not grow green-manure crops unless they abandon the use of chemical fertilizers

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This is too specific to be necessary to the argument. The farmers don’t have to grow *alfalfa* to improve the soil—they could grow other kinds of green-manure crops. Alfalfa is listed as only one type of green-manure crops.

This isn’t necessary to the argument. Green-manure crops and chemical fertilizers are both mentioned in the argument, but never in the context of adding chemical fertilizers *to* green-manure crops. In fact, the argument separates them by stating that the advent of chemical fertilizers caused farmers to *abandon* growing green-manure crops.

This is too strong to be necessary to the argument. It doesn’t have to be true that soil structure is *the most* important factor influencing the soil quality of a farm field. Soil structure could be the second most important factor, for example, and that wouldn’t affect the argument one way or another.

This doesn’t have to be true in order for the argument to work. We’re told that the soil structure worsens when *green-manure crops* aren’t grown anymore—not that chemical fertilizers directly hurt soil structure.

This has to be true in order for the argument to work. Chemical fertilizers didn’t hurt the soil; they caused farmers to stop using the thing that *helps* the soil. The arguer thus assumes that the only way to bring back the green-manure crops is to *stop* the thing that *stopped* the green-manure crops. But there are lots of potential ways to bring back green-manure crops. A necessary assumption will demonstrate that there *aren’t* other ways to bring them back. Another way to phrase this choice is: 

* The only thing that will get farmers to grow green-manure crops again is to have them *stop* using chemical fertilizers.

This *has* to be true in order for the argument to work. If it were false, and farmers who stop using chemical fertilizers *won’t* start growing green-manure crops again, then the conclusion wouldn’t follow—the soil wouldn’t be improved from halting the use of chemical fertilizers.

items.stimulusText: Most of the students who took Spanish 101 at the university last semester attended every class session. However, each student who received a grade lower than B minus missed at least one class session.
items.stemText: Which one of the following statements about the students who took Spanish 101 at the university last semester can be properly inferred from the information above?

options.optionContent: At least some of the students who received a grade of A minus or higher attended every class session.
Most, if not all, of the students who missed at least one class session received a grade lower than B minus.
Most of the students received a grade higher than B minus.
At least one student who received a grade of B minus or higher missed one or more class sessions.
More than half of the students received a grade of B minus or higher.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: The stimulus doesn't even guarantee that any student received an A- or higher (just a B- or higher), so this answer isn't supported.

This answer is a reversal of the conditional, which is illegal. (Note that there are some cases where we can reverse a conditional and change it to a some statement, but not a most statement, as this answer choice does.)

This answer choice is very close to a correct answer. However, our inference is that most of the Spanish 101 students didn't receive a grade lower than a B-, which leaves open the possibility that they all received a B-. Be careful with negations of lower than/greater than statements.
This answer is a weird half-contrapositive, half-negation of the conditional statement. That's not a legal inference.
This answer matches the valid inference we anticipated, and it distinguishes itself from (C) by including that B- grade.

items.stimulusText: Because the native salmon in Lake Clearwater had nearly disappeared, sockeye salmon were introduced in 1940. After being introduced, this genetically uniform group of sockeyes split into two distinct populations that do not interbreed, one inhabiting deep areas of the lake and the other inhabiting shallow areas. Since the two populations now differ genetically, some researchers hypothesize that each has adapted genetically to its distinct habitat.
items.stemText: Which of the following, if true, most strongly supports the researchers' hypothesis?

options.optionContent: Neither of the two populations of sockeyes has interbred with the native salmon.
When the native salmon in Lake Clearwater were numerous, they comprised two distinct populations that did not interbreed.
Most types of salmon that inhabit lakes spend part of the time in shallow water and part in deeper water.
One of the populations of sockeyes is virtually identical genetically to the sockeyes originally introduced in 1940.
The total number of sockeye salmon in the lake is not as large as the number of native salmon had been many years ago.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This supports the researchers’ hypothesis that each of the two populations adapted genetically to its habitat, because it eliminates a possible alternative explanation. If (A) is true and neither of the two populations has interbred with the native salmon, then that takes one potential weakener off of the table—it makes it impossible for the genetic difference to have been caused by interbreeding with native salmon. Any time a choice removes a potential weakener, the net effect is one of strengthening the argument.

This doesn’t support the researchers’ hypothesis. What the native salmon did when they were numerous doesn’t affect whether the two populations of sockeye salmon adapted genetically to their habitats.

This doesn’t support the researchers’ hypothesis. If anything, it could actually *weaken* it by making it more difficult for sockeye salmon to genetically adapt to a new habitat—after all, if they consistently changed habitats, which habitat would they adapt to?

This could actually *weaken* the researchers’ hypothesis. If (D) is true, then one of the populations of sockeyes would appear *not* to have adapted to its new habitat, since the population is virtually identical genetically to what it was before its introduction to the new habitat.
This information doesn’t weaken the argument. The comparative populations of sockeye salmon now to native salmon many years ago is irrelevant to an argument about genetic adaptation.

items.stimulusText: A developing country can substantially increase its economic growth if its businesspeople are willing to invest in modern industries that have not yet been pursued there. But being the first to invest in an industry is very risky. Moreover, businesspeople have little incentive to take this risk since if the business succeeds, many other people will invest in the same industry, and the competition will cut into their profits.
items.stemText: The statements above, if true, most strongly support which one of the following claims?

options.optionContent: Once a developing country has at least one business in a modern industry, further investment in that industry will not contribute to the country's economic growth.
In developing countries, there is greater competition within modern industries than within traditional industries.
A developing country can increase its prospects for economic growth by providing added incentive for investment in modern industries that have not yet been pursued there.
A developing country will not experience economic growth unless its businesspeople invest in modern industries.
Investments in a modern industry in a developing country carry little risk as long as the country has at least one other business in that industry.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: First, there's nothing in the stimulus to suggest that initial investment in an industry prevents further investment from leading to more economic growth—just that it leads to competition that affects the bottom line of the initial investor. Second, the stimulus is about substantial growth, so even if substantial growth is precluded by the stimulus by a second round of investment, some growth is still possible.

Competition in traditional industries isn't discussed in the stimulus, so there's no way to compare its level to competition in new industries. Additionally, the competition in modern industries is only mentioned in the context of successful businesses, not all businesses.

The stimulus notes that investment in new industries can lead to substantial economic growth, but that there's little incentive for businesspeople to make these investments. By removing this bar by increasing incentives, a developing country would increase the likelihood that a businessperson would be willing to take that risk, thus (based on the first conditional) increasing the likelihood that a sufficient condition for growth would be met. Note that this answer doesn't state providing these incentives will lead to economic growth, just that it "can" increase the "prospects" for economic growth—a much weaker statement that's easier to support.

Businesspeople investing is noted in the first conditional as a sufficient—not necessary—condition for economic growth, so a developing country could still see economic growth without that investment.
While being the first to invest in an industry is noted as being very risky, there's no indication that being the second to invest has "little risk"—that's a negation of the statement.

items.stimulusText: A survey of a city's concertgoers found that almost all of them were dissatisfied with the local concert hall. A large majority of them expressed a strong preference for wider seats and better acoustics. And, even though the survey respondents were told that the existing concert hall cannot feasibly be modified to provide these features, most of them opposed the idea of tearing down the existing structure and replacing it with a concert hall with wider seats and better acoustics.
items.stemText: Which one of the following, if true, most helps to explain the apparent conflict in the concertgoers' views, as revealed by the survey?

options.optionContent: Before any of the survey questions were asked, the respondents were informed that the survey was sponsored by a group that advocates replacing the existing concert hall.
Most of the people who live in the vicinity of the existing concert hall do not want it to be torn down.
The city's construction industry will receive more economic benefit from the construction of a new concert hall than from renovations to the existing concert hall.
A well-publicized plan is being considered by the city government that would convert the existing concert hall into a public auditorium and build a new concert hall nearby.
Many popular singers and musicians who currently do not hold concerts in the city would begin to hold concerts there if a new concert hall were built.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This doesn’t help explain the conflict. Nothing in the passage suggests that the respondents would be influenced by the knowledge that the survey administrators support replacing the existing concert hall.
This doesn’t help explain the conflict. We don’t know how much overlap there is between the survey respondents and people who live in the vicinity of the existing concert hall.

This comparison doesn’t help explain the conflict. Economic benefits to the city’s construction industry isn’t explicitly relevant to this situation, since we can’t know what incentive the specific survey respondents might have to want to help the construction industry. If anything, this actually deepens the mystery, because it provides one more reason to replace the concert hall with a new one.

This helps explain the survey answers. We might have formulated the conflict as, “Why did most respondents oppose the idea of replacing the concert hall with wider seats and better acoustics, when a large majority of the respondents expressed a strong preference for wider seats and better acoustics?” If (D) is true, then concertgoers would likely have known about this plan to build a new concert hall nearby, so it would be reasonable for them to oppose replacing the current concert hall, knowing that a *new* concert hall might be constructed nearby.

This doesn’t help explain the conflict, and could actually *worsen* the conflict. If replacing the concert hall would draw more popular singers and musicians, then it would be reasonable to think that the concertgoers would actually *support* the measure of replacing the concert hall.

items.stimulusText: Student: Before completing my research paper, I want to find the book from which I copied a passage to quote in the paper. Without the book, I will be unable to write an accurate citation, and without an accurate citation, I will be unable to include the quotation. Hence, since the completed paper will be much better with the quotation than without, _______.
items.stemText: Which one of the following most logically completes the student's argument?

options.optionContent: I will have to include an inaccurate citation
I will be unable to complete my research paper
if I do not find the book, my research paper will suffer
if I do not find the book, I will include the quotation without an accurate citation
if I do not find the book, I will be unable to complete my research paper

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: First, there's no indication that the Student won't be able to find the book—the substantive portions of the stimulus are conditional. Second, even if the student can't find the book, she can still omit the quote and submit a worse paper—there's nothing forcing her to include the quote with an inaccurate citation. In fact, the Student sets out that being forced to include an inaccurate citation is sufficient for her to leave the quote out altogether, thus also eliminating the need for any type of citation.
There's no indication that failing to complete the research paper is on the table at all.

This answer brings together the conditional chain that the Student walks through in describing the impact of not finding the book. It maintains the conditional nature of the premises, as well, so it's the correct completion to the argument.
Without the book, the Student says she'll be "unable to include the quotation," so this answer choice is contradicted by the premises in the stimulus.
Similar to (B), there's no indication that failing to complete the research paper is on the table. Any answer that brings up failure to complete is out of scope.

content: Susan Milius, "Built for Blurs." ©2005 by Science Services, Inc.

sections.directions: Directions: Each set of questions in this section is based on a single passage or a pair of passages. The questions are to be answered on the basis of what is stated or implied in the passage or pair of passages. For some questions, more than one of the choices could conceivably answer the question. However, you are to choose the best answer; that is, choose the response that most accurately and completely answers the question.

items.stimulusText:
An organism is considered to have an infection when a disease-causing agent, called a pathogen, establishes a viable presence in the organism. This can occur only if the pathogenic agent is able to reproduce itself in the host organism. The only agents believed until recently to be responsible for infections—viruses, bacteria, fungi, and parasites—reproduce and regulate their other life processes by means of genetic material, composed of nucleic acid (DNA or RNA). It was thus widely assumed that all pathogens contain such genetic material in their cellular structure.

This assumption has been challenged, however, by scientists seeking to identify the pathogen that causes Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD), a degenerative form of dementia in humans. CJD causes the brain to become riddled with tiny holes, like a sponge (evidence of extensive nerve cell death). Its symptoms include impaired muscle control, loss of mental acuity, memory loss, and chronic insomnia. Extensive experiments aimed at identifying the pathogen responsible for CJD have led surprisingly to the isolation of a disease agent lacking nucleic acid and consisting mainly, if not exclusively, of protein. Researchers coined the term "prion" for this new type of protein pathogen.

Upon further study, scientists discovered that prions normally exist as harmless cellular proteins in many of the body's tissues, including white blood cells and nerve cells in the brain; however, they possess the capability of converting their structures into a dangerous abnormal shape. Prions exhibiting this abnormal conformation were found to have infectious properties and the ability to reproduce themselves in an unexpected way, by initiating a chain reaction that induces normally shaped prions to transform themselves on contact, one after another, into the abnormal, pathogenic conformation. This cascade of transformations produces a plaque, consisting of thread-like structures, that collects in the brain and ultimately destroys nerve cells. Because prions, unlike other pathogens, occur naturally in the body as proteins, the body does not produce an immune response when they are present. And in the absence of any effective therapy for preventing the cascade process by which affected prions reproduce themselves, CJD is inevitably fatal, though there are wide variations in pre-symptomatic incubation times and in how aggressively the disease progresses.

Although the discovery of the link between prions and CJD was initially received with great skepticism in the scientific community, subsequent research has supported the conclusion that prions are an entirely new class of infectious pathogens. Furthermore, it is now believed that a similar process of protein malformation may be involved in other, more common degenerative neurological conditions such as Alzheimer's disease and Parkinson's disease. This possibility has yet to be fully explored, however, and the exact mechanisms by which prions reproduce themselves and cause cellular destruction have yet to be completely understood.
items.stemText: Which one of the following most accurately expresses the main point of the passage?

options.optionContent: Although most organisms are known to produce several kinds of proteins, the mechanism by which isolated protein molecules such as prions reproduce themselves is not yet known in detail.
Research into the cause of CJD has uncovered a deadly class of protein pathogens uniquely capable of reproducing themselves without genetic material.
Recent research suggests that prions may be responsible not only for CJD, but for most other degenerative neurological conditions as well.
The assertion that prions cause CJD has been received with great skepticism in the scientific community because it undermines a firmly entrenched view about the nature of pathogens.
Even though prions contain no genetic material, it has become clear that they are somehow capable of reproducing themselves.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This is not the main point of the passage. First, whether *most organisms* are known to produce several kinds of proteins is out of the scope of the passage, which focuses instead on prions occurring within *the human body*. Second, while the passage does say that the prion reproductive mechanism is not yet known in detail, this is too narrow to be the main point—the passage focuses more broadly on the discovery and impact of prions.

This accurately states the main point of the passage. The passage starts by explaining the formerly widespread belief that pathogens contain their own genetic material, and then delves into how research into CJD led to the discovery of prions, which are protein-based pathogens that do *not* have their own genetic material.

This is too strong—the passage states that prions may be *involved* in *other, more common* neurodegenerative diseases, but it doesn’t say that prions are *responsible* for *most* other neurodegenerative diseases.

This is an accurate *supporting detail*, but it’s too narrow to be the main point of the passage. The passage focuses more broadly on the discovery and impact of prions, ultimately asserting that prions overcame the initial skepticism in the scientific community and are now believed to play a part in other, more common neurodegenerative diseases.
This is an accurate *supporting detail*, but it’s too narrow to be the main point of the passage, which focuses more broadly on the discovery and impact of prions.

items.questionType: Identifying Main Points and Primary Purposes
items.displayType: Identifying Main Points and Primary Purposes

items.stemText: Which one of the following is most strongly supported by the passage?

options.optionContent: Understanding the cause of CJD has required scientists to reconsider their traditional beliefs about the causes of infection.
CJD is contagious, though not highly so.
The prevention of CJD would be most efficiently achieved by the prevention of certain genetic abnormalities.
Although patients with CJD exhibit different incubation times, the disease progresses at about the same rate in all patients once symptoms are manifested.
The prion theory of infection has weak support within the scientific community.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This is strongly supported by the passage. First, the passage states that all previously known pathogens have their own genetic material, which prions don't—they are an entirely new class of pathogen. The passage then states that their discovery was received with “great skepticism” by the scientific community, but that they were eventually accepted after further research, and are now even believed to play a role in more common neurodegenerative diseases. All in all, this suggests that scientists had to reconsider their traditional beliefs about pathogens (that they must have their own genetic material) in order to accept prions as the cause of CJD.

There is no indication in the passage that CJD is contagious. The passage states that prions start as proteins that naturally occur in the body and then morph into a dangerous abnormal shape, infecting other prions in the body on contact. Whether this process could infect *other* bodies is never discussed.

The passage indicates that CJD is caused by abnormally formed prions. But the passage does not indicate that **genetic** abnormalities have anything to do do with abnormal prions (or with CJD in any other way). So the passage gives us no reason to infer that the most efficient way to prevent CJD would have anything to do with preventing genetic abnormalities.

This conflicts with the passage: though CJD is inevitably fatal, the third paragraph states that there are “wide variations in pre-symptomatic incubation times **and in how aggressively the disease progresses**.”

This conflicts with the passage, which says that the prion theory was *initially* met with skepticism, but then subsequent research “supported the conclusion that prions are an entirely new class of infectious pathogens,” and now it is even believed that “a similar process of protein malformation” may be involved in other neurodegenerative diseases. This implies that the prion theory now has *fairly strong* support within the scientific community.

items.stemText: If the hypothesis that CJD is caused by prions is correct, finding the answer to which one of the following questions would tend most to help a physician in deciding whether a patient has CJD?

options.optionContent: Has the patient suffered a severe blow to the skull recently?
Does the patient experience occasional bouts of insomnia?
Has the patient been exposed to any forms of radiation that have a known tendency to cause certain kinds of genetic damage?
Has any member of the patient's immediate family ever had a brain disease?
Does the patient's brain tissue exhibit the presence of any abnormal thread-like structures?

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: Blows to the skull are not mentioned as a cause of prion formation (or of CJD), and are in fact never discussed in the passage at all. So it’s unlikely that the answer to this question would help a physician diagnose CJD.
The second paragraph lists *“chronic”* insomnia—not *occasional* insomnia—as a symptom of CJD. So it’s unlikely that the answer to this question would help a physician diagnose CJD.

Radiation-induced genetic damage is not discussed in the passage at all, let alone as a cause of prion formation (or of CJD). So it’s unlikely that the answer to this question would help a physician diagnose CJD.

The passage never discusses whether or not prion formation (or CJD) is more likely to occur in individuals with a family history of brain disease. So it’s unlikely that the answer to this question would help a physician diagnose CJD.

The hypothesis for how prions cause CJD, as described in the passage, is that prions reproduce via a cascade of transformations upon contact, which then “produces a plaque, consisting of **thread-like structures**, that collects in the brain and ultimately destroys nerve cells.” Thus, if this hypothesis is correct, the presence of these abnormal thread-like structures in the brain would indicate that the patient has CJD.

items.questionType: Applying the Argument to New Contexts
items.displayType: Applying the Argument to New Contexts

items.stemText: Which one of the following is most strongly supported by the passage?

options.optionContent: The only way in which CJD can be transmitted is through the injection of abnormally shaped prions from an infected individual into an uninfected individual.
Most infectious diseases previously thought to be caused by other pathogens are now thought to be caused by prions.
If they were unable to reproduce themselves, abnormally shaped prions would not cause CJD.
Alzheimer's disease and Parkinson's disease are caused by different conformations of the same prion pathogen that causes CJD.
Prion diseases generally progress more aggressively than diseases caused by other known pathogens.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: There’s no discussion of how CJD can be transmitted from one person to another in the passage; in fact, there’s nothing in the passage that indicates it is even possible to transmit the disease.

This is way too strong. As described in the last paragraph, it’s not that *most* infectious diseases are now thought to be caused by prions; it’s that “a similar process of protein malformation” may play a role in “other, more common neurological conditions such as Alzheimer's disease and Parkinson's disease.”

The third paragraph describes how prions cause CJD: the “cascade of transformations” that is prion reproduction produces plaque, and that plaque destroys nerve cells. So, we can infer that if prions *weren’t* able to reproduce (i.e., couldn’t initiate this cascade of protein malformations), then there would be no plaque, and CJD wouldn’t occur.

The last paragraph states that “a **similar process** of protein malformation may be involved in other, more common degenerative neurological conditions such as Alzheimer's disease and Parkinson's disease.” But the passage never specifies beyond that at all; it certainly doesn’t suggest that these diseases are caused by different conformations of the same prion pathogen.

The passage never compares the progression of prion diseases to the progression of diseases caused by other known pathogens. In fact, it never discusses the progression of diseases caused by other known pathogens *at all*. So this can’t be supported by the passage.
