items.stemText: It can be inferred from the passage that the author would be least likely to agree with which one of the following?

options.optionContent: The presence of certain abnormally shaped prions in brain tissue is a sign of neurological disease.
Some patients currently infected with CJD will recover from the disease.
Prions do not require nucleic acid for their reproduction.
The body has no natural defense against CJD.
Scientists have only a partial understanding of the mechanism by which prions reproduce.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: The author would likely *agree* with this, since the author presents the theory that abnormally shaped prions cause neurological disease as a theory that has been supported by subsequent research and that has been accepted by the scientific community (though some specifics are still unknown).

In the third paragraph, the author writes that, given the absence of a treatment that prevents prion reproduction, “CJD is **inevitably** fatal.” So the author would be highly unlikely to agree that anyone at all will recover from CJD.

The author would be likely to agree with this, since prions *do not* have their own genetic material (i.e., no nucleic acid), but can still reproduce by initiating a chain reaction that induces normally shaped prions to transform themselves on contact into the pathogenic conformation.

In the third paragraph, the author writes that the body “does not produce an immune response” to prions. However, the author never says or implies that the body has *no* natural defense against CJD at all. So the author doesn’t exclude the possibility that there is a natural defense against prion reproduction that *isn’t* an immune system response. Hence, we can’t say that the author would be unlikely to agree with this statement.

The author would likely agree with this. The author says as much in the last sentence of the passage: “and the exact mechanisms by which prions reproduce themselves...have yet to be completely understood.”

items.stemText: Given the manner in which the term "pathogen" is used in the passage, and assuming that the prion theory of infection is correct, which one of the following statements must be false?

options.optionContent: Nothing that lacks nucleic acid is a pathogen.
Prions are a relatively newly discovered type of pathogen.
All pathogens can cause infection.
Pathogens contribute in some manner to the occurrence of CJD.
There are other pathogens besides viruses, bacteria, fungi, and parasites.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: If the prion theory of infection is correct, then prions classify as pathogens (disease-causing agents), even though they don’t have their own DNA or RNA (i.e. don’t have their own nucleic acid)—so this statement would have to be false.

This would be true. Though the passage never explicitly says so, we can discern the relative newness of the discovery of prions based on the descriptions given in the passage: the theory was “initially” met with skepticism, but “subsequent” research has supported it, supplanting the once “widely assumed” hypothesis that pathogens must have their own DNA or RNA.
This would be true. The definition of a pathogen given in the passage is “a disease-causing agent.” Thus, by definition, all pathogens can cause infection.
This would be true. If the prion theory is correct, then prions—which cause CJD—*are* pathogens, so pathogens *do* contribute to the occurrence of CJD.
This would be true. If the prion theory is correct, then prions are another kind of pathogen (NOT belonging to one of these four categories).

items.stemText: Which one of the following, if true, would most undermine the claim that prions cause CJD?

options.optionContent: Several symptoms closely resembling those of CJD have been experienced by patients known to have a specific viral infection.
None of the therapies currently available for treating neurological diseases is designed to block the chain reaction by which abnormal prions are believed to reproduce.
Research undertaken subsequent to the studies on CJD has linked prions to degenerative conditions not affecting the brain or the central nervous system.
Epidemiological studies carried out on a large population have failed to show any hereditary predisposition to CJD.
A newly developed antibacterial drug currently undergoing clinical trials is proving to be effective in reversing the onset of CJD.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This doesn’t undermine the claim that prions cause CJD. For one thing, correlation does not imply causation: just because the patients **have** a virus and certain CJD-like symptoms doesn’t mean that the virus **caused** the symptoms. For another thing, just because their symptoms **resemble** CJD doesn’t mean that the patients **have** CJD—there are probably other conditions (viral and otherwise) with similar symptoms out there.

This doesn’t undermine the claim that prions cause CJD—in fact, this information is brought up by the author in the third paragraph. The author states that CJD is always fatal *given that* there are no therapies to prevent prion reproduction.

This doesn’t undermine the claim that prions cause CJD—if prions play a role in other degenerative conditions not affecting the brain or CNS, that strengthens the author’s broader claim that prions are indeed pathogens (disease-causing agents). In other words, it doesn’t weaken the causal link between CJD and prions; it just broadens the pathogenic role of prions to *also* include other areas of the body.
This doesn’t undermine the claim that prions cause CJD—the passage never says that hereditary predisposition is correlated with prions, their reproduction, or the occurrence of CJD in any way.

If an antibacterial drug reverses the onset of CJD, then that directly implies that some kind of bacterium—*not* prions—causes CJD. So, if true, this would seriously undermine the claim that prions cause CJD.

items.stimulusText:
One of the more striking developments in modern North American dance was African American choreographer Katherine Dunham's introduction of a technique known as dance-isolation, in which one part of the body moves in one rhythm while other parts are kept stationary or are moved in different rhythms. The incorporation of this technique into North American and European choreography is relatively recent, although various forms of the technique have long been essential to traditional dances of certain African, Caribbean, and Pacific-island cultures. Dunham's success in bringing dance-isolation and other traditional techniques from those cultures into the mainstream of modern North American dance is due in no small part to her training in both anthropological research and choreography.

As an anthropologist in the 1930s, Dunham was one of the pioneers in the field of dance ethnology. Previously, dance had been neglected as an area of social research, primarily because most social scientists gravitated toward areas likely to be recognized by their peers as befitting scientifically rigorous, and therefore legitimate, modes of inquiry. Moreover, no other social scientist at that time was sufficiently trained in dance to be able to understand dance techniques, while experts in dance were not trained in the methods of social research.

Starting in 1935, Dunham conducted a series of research projects into traditional Caribbean dance forms, with special interest in their origins in African culture. Especially critical to her success was her approach to research, which diverged radically from the methodology that prevailed at the time. Colleagues in anthropology advised her not to become too closely involved in the dances she was observing, both because of the extreme physical demands of the dances, and because they subscribed to the long-standing view, now fortunately recognized as unrealistic, that effective data gathering can and must be conducted from a position of complete detachment. But because of her interest and her skill as a performer, she generally eschewed such caution and participated in the dances herself. Through prolonged immersion of this kind, Dunham was able not only to comprehend various dances as complex cultural practices, but also to learn the techniques well enough to teach them to others and incorporate them into new forms of ballet.

Between 1937 and 1945, Dunham developed a research-to-performance method that she used to adapt Caribbean dance forms for use in theatrical performance, combining them with modern dance styles she learned in Chicago. The ballets she created in this fashion were among the first North American dances to rectify the exclusion of African American themes from the medium of modern dance. Her work was thus crucial in establishing African American dance as an art form in its own right, making possible future companies such as Arthur Mitchell's Dance Theater of Harlem.
items.stemText: Which one of the following most accurately expresses the main point of the passage?

options.optionContent: Katherine Dunham transformed the field of anthropology by developing innovative research methodologies for studying Caribbean and other traditional dance styles and connecting them with African American dance.
Katherine Dunham's ballets were distinct from others produced in North America in that they incorporated authentic dance techniques from traditional cultures.

Katherine Dunham's expertise as an anthropologist allowed her to use Caribbean and African dance traditions to express the aesthetic and political concerns of African American dancers and choreographers.
The innovative research methods of Katherine Dunham made possible her discovery that the dance traditions of the Caribbean were derived from earlier African dance traditions.
Katherine Dunham's anthropological and choreographic expertise enabled her to make contributions that altered the landscape of modern dance in North America.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This mischaracterizes the focus of passage. The passage isn’t so much about how Dunham transformed *anthropology* as it is about how her innovative anthropological work helped her go on to transform *modern dance*.

This goes beyond what we can tell from the passage. The passage never says that no other North American ballets incorporated authentic dance techniques from *any* traditional culture—just that Dunham incorporated *specifically* Afro-Caribbean traditional dance techniques, and was *among* the first to do so. Besides, this choice is too narrow to cover the main point of the passage, because it doesn’t touch on Dunham’s anthropological research.

The passage never says that Dunham used Caribbean and African dance traditions to express the aesthetic and political concerns of African American dancers and choreographers. The last paragraph says that her work in incorporating Caribbean and African dance techniques into modern dance was crucial for “establishing African American dance as an art form in its own right,” but never that she expressed any African American concerns with the dance traditions she studied and incorporated. So this doesn’t reflect *any* point in the passage, let alone the main point.

The passage never states that Dunham *discovered* that the dance traditions of the Caribbean were derived from earlier African dance traditions. In fact, the first sentence of the third paragraph implies that it was already known that these dance traditions had African origins: “Starting in 1935, Dunham conducted a series of research projects into traditional Caribbean dance forms, with special interest in their origins in African culture.” So this doesn’t reflect *any* point in the passage, let alone the main point.

This accurately sums up the main point of the passage. Overall, the passage argues that the combination of Dunham’s skills as a social researcher *and* as a dancer/choreographer are what enabled her to make such a big impact on North American modern dance. Each paragraph serves that broader goal: The first paragraph states this thesis; the second explains why other social researchers had ignored dance as an area of study; the third discusses Dunham’s unorthodox method of learning and participating in the dances themselves; and the final paragraph connects her method of immersion with the significant legacy she left by being the first to incorporate African themes into modern dance.

items.stemText: According to the passage, Dunham's work in anthropology differed from that of most other anthropologists in the 1930s in that Dunham

options.optionContent: performed fieldwork for a very extended time period
related the traditions she studied to those of her own culture
employed a participative approach in performing research
attached a high degree of political significance to her research
had prior familiarity with the cultural practices of the peoples she set out to study

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: The passage never says that Dunham performed fieldwork for a very extended time period, and it also never says that the other anthropologists of the 1930s didn’t do just that. So there’s no support for this in the passage.
There’s no support for this choice; the passage never says or implies that other anthropologists didn’t related the traditions they studied to those of their own cultures.

The second paragraph describes how Dunham’s anthropological approach “differed radically” from the prevailing methodology in the 1930s in that Dunham did not gather data “from a position of complete detachment,” but rather “eschewed such caution and participated in the dances herself.” In other words, her work in anthropology differed from other anthropologists’ work in that she participated in performing her research.

This is out of scope. The passage never says that other anthropologists of the 1930s didn’t attach a high degree of political significance to their research. Also, although the passage might imply that Dunham's work, by correcting the exclusion of African American themes from modern dance, had political (or at least social) consequences, the passage does not state that Dunham **herself** considered her work highly political.

This is out of scope. The passage never says that Dunham had prior familiarity with the cultural practices of the peoples she set out to study, or that this is what makes her work distinctive from other anthropologists of the time.

items.stemText: The passage suggests that the "peers" mentioned in the second sentence of the second paragraph would have been most likely to agree with which one of the following statements about the study of dance?

options.optionContent: Most social scientists who have attempted to study dance as a cultural phenomenon have misinterpreted it.
Social scientists need not be well versed in dance traditions in order to obtain reliable data about them.
Research into dance as a cultural form cannot be conducted with a high degree of scientific precision.
Most experts in the field of dance are too preoccupied to conduct studies in the field of dance ethnology.
Dance forms are too variable across cultures to permit rigorous means of data collection.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: The passage states that “Previously, dance had been neglected as an area of social research, primarily because most social scientists gravitated toward areas likely to be recognized by their peers as **befitting scientifically rigorous, and therefore legitimate, modes of inquiry**.” We can infer from this that the “peers” would have believed that the study of dance can’t be scientifically rigorous—*not* that most social scientists have misinterpreted dance. In fact, this excerpt suggests that almost no social scientists even attempted to study dance as a cultural phenomenon before Dunham, let alone attempted and misinterpreted it.

The passage states that “Previously, dance had been neglected as an area of social research, primarily because most social scientists gravitated toward areas likely to be recognized by their peers as **befitting scientifically rigorous, and therefore legitimate, modes of inquiry**.” We can infer that the “peers” would have believed that the study of dance can’t be scientifically rigorous. 

Then, the passage goes on to state that “no other social scientist at that time was sufficiently trained in dance to be able to understand dance techniques,” which implies that the peers would have believed social scientists *should* be well versed in dance traditions in order to obtain reliable data about them.

The passage states that “Previously, dance had been neglected as an area of social research, primarily because most social scientists gravitated toward areas likely to be recognized by their peers as **befitting scientifically rigorous, and therefore legitimate, modes of inquiry**.” We can infer that these “peers” would have believed the study of dance does *not* lend itself to scientifically rigorous inquiry, i.e., studies would be unable to be conducted with a high degree of scientific precision.

The passage states that “Previously, dance had been neglected as an area of social research, primarily because most social scientists gravitated toward areas likely to be recognized by their peers as **befitting scientifically rigorous, and therefore legitimate, modes of inquiry**.” We can infer that the “peers” would have believed that the study of dance can’t be scientifically rigorous. The passage does go on to mention experts in the field of dance, but no views about those dance experts are ascribed to social scientists of the 1930s and earlier (the “peers”), and there’s no indication that *anybody* considered dance experts “preoccupied.”

There’s nothing in the passage to suggest that the “peers” would have believed that dance forms are *too variable*—the reason why the study of dance was not believed to be “befitting scientifically rigorous, and therefore legitimate, modes of inquiry” is never given.

items.stemText: In the last sentence of the second paragraph, the author mentions "experts in dance" primarily in order to

options.optionContent: suggest why a group of social scientists did not embrace the study of a particular cultural form
suggest that a certain group was more qualified to study a particular cultural form than was another group
identify an additional factor that motivated a particular social scientist to pursue a specific new line of research
contribute to an explanation of why a particular field of research was not previously pursued
indicate an additional possible reason for the tension between the members of two distinct fields of research

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This paragraph does offer an explanation for why social scientists *in general* did not embrace the study of dance, but there’s no *group* of social scientists singled out—it’s implied that most, if not all, social researchers didn’t embrace dance ethnology. So the reason the author brings up “experts in dance” is actually to contribute to their explanation of why dance ethnology had been neglected by social researchers *as a whole* before Dunham.

Both “groups” brought up here (dance experts and social scientists) are described as being *unqualified* to study dance ethnology, because each group lacks training in one area or the other. So this can’t be the reason the author mentions "experts in dance."

Rather, in this paragraph, the author first posits that dance had been neglected by social scientists, and then states three points explaining why, the last of which is that no “experts in dance” had the anthropological training necessary to engage in that kind of study themselves. Thus, the reason the author brings up “experts in dance” in this context is actually to contribute to their explanation of why dance ethnology had been neglected by social researchers before Dunham.

The “experts in dance” are not brought up as part of explaining Dunham’s motives. In this paragraph, the author first posits that dance had been neglected by social scientists, and then states three points explaining why: that social scientists gravitated toward areas of study that came off as more legitimate; that no other social scientists of the time had the training in dance necessary to evaluate dance techniques; and that (conversely) no “experts in dance” had the anthropological training necessary to engage in that kind of study themselves. Thus, the reason the author brings up “experts in dance” in this context is actually to contribute to their explanation of why dance ethnology had been neglected by social researchers before Dunham.

In this paragraph, the author first posits that, before Dunham, dance ethnology had been neglected as a field of research, and then states three points explaining why: that social scientists gravitated toward areas of study that seemed more legitimate; that no other social scientists of the time had the training in dance necessary to evaluate dance techniques; and that (conversely) no “experts in dance” had the anthropological training necessary to engage in that kind of study themselves. Thus, the reason the author brings up “experts in dance” in this context is to contribute to their explanation of why dance ethnology had been neglected by social researchers before Dunham.

No tension between members of distinct fields of research is brought up—in fact, the “experts in dance” are not identified as members of a field of research at all. In this paragraph, the author first posits that dance had been neglected by social scientists, and then states three points explaining why: that social scientists gravitated toward areas of study that came off as more legitimate; that no other social scientists of the time had the training in dance necessary to evaluate dance techniques; and that (conversely) no “experts in dance” had the anthropological training necessary to engage in that kind of study themselves. Thus, the reason the author brings up “experts in dance” in this context is actually to contribute to their explanation of why dance ethnology had been neglected by social researchers before Dunham.

items.stemText: According to the passage, which one of the following was true of the dance forms that Dunham began studying in 1935?

options.optionContent: They were more similar to dance forms used in Pacific-island cultures than to any other known dance forms.
They represented the first use of the technique of dance-isolation within a culture outside of Africa.
They shared certain rhythmic characteristics with the dance forms employed in North American ballets.
They had already influenced certain popular dances in North America.
They were influenced by the traditions of non-Caribbean cultures.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: There’s nothing in the passage to indicate that this statement is true of the dance forms Dunham began studying in 1935. The first paragraph says that various forms of the dance-isolation technique, which Dunham incorporated into North American dances, “have long been essential to traditional dances of certain African, Caribbean, and Pacific-island cultures.” But the passage never claims that the dance forms Dunham studied were *more similar* to those in Pacific-island cultures than to those of the other cultures mentioned.

There’s nothing in the passage to indicate that this statement is true of the dance forms Dunham began studying in 1935. The first paragraph says that “various forms of the technique [of dance-isolation] have long been essential to traditional dances of certain African, Caribbean, and Pacific-island cultures.” Then, the third paragraph says that Dunham specifically studied Caribbean dance forms that had origins in African culture. But the passage never says that these Caribbean cultures had used dance-isolation *before* the Pacific-island cultures did, so we can’t say that the dance forms Dunham began studying in 1935 represented the *first* use of the technique of dance-isolation within a culture outside of Africa.

There’s nothing in the passage that states that the dance forms Dunham began studying in 1935 had anything in common with dance forms employed at the time in North American ballets, let alone that they shared certain rhythmic characteristics.

This conflicts with the passage, which implies that Dunham was the first to introduce the Caribbean dance forms she studied into North American dances, meaning they couldn’t have already influenced certain popular dances in North America *before* she began studying them.

The passage discusses the dance forms Dunham began studying in 1935 in the third paragraph. The first sentence reads: “Starting in 1935, Dunham conducted a series of research projects into traditional Caribbean dance forms, with special interest in **their origins in African culture.**” In other words, these Caribbean dance forms were influenced by African cultural traditions.

items.stemText: Which one of the following is most analogous to Dunham's work in anthropology and choreography as that work is described in the passage?

options.optionContent: A French archaeologist with training in musicology researches instruments used in seventeenth century France, and her findings become the basis for a Korean engineer's designs for devices to simulate the sounds those instruments most likely made.

An Australian medical researcher with training in botany analyzes the chemical composition of plants that other researchers have collected in the Philippines, and then an Australian pharmaceutical company uses her findings to develop successful new medicines.

A Canadian surgeon uses her skill in drawing to collaborate with a Vietnamese surgeon to develop a manual containing detailed illustrations of the proper techniques for certain types of reconstructive surgery performed in both countries.

A Brazilian teacher with training in social psychology conducts a detailed study of teaching procedures while working with teachers in several Asian countries, then introduces the most effective of those procedures to teachers in his own country.

An Italian fashion designer researches the social significance of clothing design in several cultures and then presents his research in a highly acclaimed book directed toward his colleagues in fashion design.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This is an example of a professional from one field incorporating the results of a professional from another field into their own work. So it’s not quite analogous to Dunham’s work, as described in the passage—Dunham applied *her own* results from one field to another.

This is an example of a *company* building upon the results of *an individual researcher*, all within *the same* field. So it’s not quite analogous to Dunham’s work, as described in the passage—Dunham applied *her own* results from one field *to another*.

This is an example of a *two* different people from *the same* field but different countries collaborating. So it’s not quite analogous to Dunham’s work, as described in the passage—Dunham applied *her own* results from one field *to another*.

This is analogous to Dunham’s work, as described in the passage: a professional with training in two different fields (Dunham, or in this case the Brazilian teacher) goes abroad and leverages their skills in *one* of the fields to conduct research into the *other* field, then broadens the latter field at home by incorporating the results of this research.

This is close, but it’s not quite analogous to Dunham’s work, as described in the passage. The key difference between this Italian fashion designer and Dunham is that Dunham actually incorporated the dance forms from the cultures she studied *into* her own country’s dance forms. So, if the Italian designer had incorporated the different cultures’ fashion designs *into Italian fashion*, adding to the diversity and multiculturalism of Italian fashion, then this situation would be more analogous.

items.stemText: The passage suggests that the author would be most likely to agree with which one of the following statements about the colleagues mentioned in the third sentence of the third paragraph?

options.optionContent: They were partly correct in recommending that Dunham change her methods of data collection, since injury sustained during fieldwork might have compromised her research.
They were partly correct in advising Dunham to exercise initial caution in participating in the Caribbean dances, since her skill in performing them improved with experience.
They were incorrect in advising Dunham to increase the degree of her detachment, since extensive personal investment in fieldwork generally enhances scientific rigor.
They were incorrect in assuming that researchers in the social sciences are able to gather data in an entirely objective manner.
They were incorrect in assuming that dance could be studied with the same degree of scientific rigor possible in other areas of ethnology.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation:
There’s nothing about injury sustained during fieldwork in the passage, and that’s not the reason Dunham’s “colleagues” advised her to change her methods. Rather, her “colleagues” advised Dunham “not to become too closely involved” in the dances she was studying in order to **most effectively gather data**—and the author immediately says that this idea is “now fortunately recognized as **unrealistic**,” so we can infer that the author thinks these colleagues were incorrect. 

Also, note that the "colleagues" referenced here are people who specifically worked with Dunham, not the "peers" mentioned earlier in the passage. These "peers" represent social scientists in general, not those who had contact with Dunham's work.

There’s nothing about Dunham’s skills improving or not improving at all in the passage. Rather, the “colleagues” advised Dunham “not to become too closely involved” in the dances she was studying in order to **most effectively gather data**—and the author immediately says that this idea is “now fortunately recognized as **unrealistic**,” so we can infer that the author thinks these colleagues were incorrect. 

Also, note that the "colleagues" referenced here are people who specifically worked with Dunham, not the "peers" mentioned earlier in the passage. These "peers" represent social scientists in general, not those who had contact with Dunham's work.

The first part of this is supported: we can infer that the author thinks these colleagues were incorrect. However, the *reason* why the author believes they were incorrect is not that extensive personal investment in fieldwork generally enhances scientific rigor. Rather, the author believes they were incorrect because complete detachment in data-gathering “is now fortunately recognized as **unrealistic**.” Besides, according to the passage, Dunham’s personal immersion in the dance forms didn’t necessarily contribute to greater scientific rigor in her studies—rather, her participation in the dance forms led directly to her incorporating these forms into North American dances as a choreographer.  

Also, note that the "colleagues" referenced here are people who specifically worked with Dunham, not the "peers" mentioned earlier in the passage. These "peers" represent social scientists in general, not those who had contact with Dunham's work.

The “colleagues” advised Dunham “not to become too closely involved” in the dances she was studying in order to most effectively collect data, but the author immediately says that this idea is “now fortunately recognized as **unrealistic**.” So we can infer that the author believes these colleagues were incorrect in assuming that researchers in the social sciences are even *able* to gather data in an entirely objective manner.

The first part of this is supported: we can infer that the author thinks these colleagues were incorrect. However, the *reason* why the author believes they were incorrect is not that dance can’t be studied with the same degree of scientific rigor possible in other areas of ethnology. Rather, the author believes they were incorrect because the idea that complete detachment is even possible for data-gathering in general “is now fortunately recognized as **unrealistic**.” 

Also, note that the "colleagues" referenced here are people who specifically worked with Dunham, not the "peers" mentioned earlier in the passage. These "peers" represent social scientists in general, not those who had contact with Dunham's work.

items.stimulusText:
Passage A

Research concerning happiness and wealth reveals a paradox: at any one time richer people report higher levels of happiness than poorer people in the same society report, and yet over time advanced societies have not grown happier as they have grown richer. Apparently, people are comparing their income with some norm, and that norm must be rising along with actual income. Two phenomena—habituation and rivalry—push up the norm.

When our living standards increase, we love it initially but then we adjust and it makes little difference. For example, if we ask people with different incomes what income they consider sufficient, the "required income" correlates strongly with their actual income: a rise in actual income causes a roughly equivalent rise in required income. We can also look at reported happiness over time. Job satisfaction depends little on the absolute level of wages but rises if wages rapidly increase.

We do not have the same experience with other aspects of our lives. We do not foresee how we adjust to material possessions, so we overinvest in acquiring them, at the expense of leisure.

Now consider the phenomenon of rivalry. In a study conducted by Solnick and Hemenway, people were asked to choose between two options, with all prices held constant:

A. You earn $50,000 a year while everyone else earns $25,000;

B. You earn $100,000 a year while others make $200,000.

The majority chose the first. They were happy to be poorer, provided their relative position improved.

And indeed, how people compare to their "reference group"—those most like them—is crucial for happiness. In East Germany, for example, living standards have soared since 1990, but the level of happiness has plummeted because people now compare themselves with West Germans, rather than with people in other Soviet bloc countries.

Passage B

Does the Solnick and Hemenway study mean that we care most about one-upmanship? Perhaps out of our primeval past comes the urge to demonstrate our superiority in order to help ensure mating prospects, keeping our genetic lines going. Still programmed like this, we get unexplainable pleasure from having a bigger house than our neighbors.

This theory may sound good and is commonly heard, but it is not the explanation best supported by the evidence. Rather, the data show that earning more makes people happier because relative prosperity makes them feel that they are successful, that they have created value.

If two people feel equally successful, they will be equally happy even if their incomes differ greatly. Of course, people who earn more generally view themselves as successful. But it is the success—not the money per se—that provides the happiness. We use material wealth to show not just that we are prosperous, but that we are prosperous because we create value.

What scholars often portray as an ignoble tendency—wanting to have more than others—is really evidence of a desire to create value. Wanting to create value benefits society. It is a bonus that it also brings happiness.
items.stemText: Both passages are primarily concerned with explaining which one of the following?

options.optionContent: the human desire to create value
the relationship between income and happiness
the biological basis of people's attitudes toward wealth
the human propensity to become habituated to wealth
the concept of "required income"

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: That the human desire to create value *explains the research findings about wealth and happiness* is the thesis of passage B, but passage A doesn't touch upon this at all.

Though the passages have different theses, both are primarily concerned with explaining the relationship between income and happiness: passage A argues that the phenomena of habituation and rivalry explain this relationship, and passage B argues that the desire to create value is the better explanation.

Passage A doesn’t delve into biological reasoning at all, and passage B only mentions a biological explanation very briefly (which it then dismisses). So neither passage is primarily concerned with the biological basis of people's attitudes toward wealth.
Habituation is a sub-point discussed in passage A, but this is too narrow to be the primary concern of the passage—and passage B doesn't discuss habituation at all.

“Required income” is discussed in passage A, but this is too narrow to be the primary concern of the passage. The concept is somewhat implicitly woven into passage B, but it isn't discussed outright, and is still too narrow to encompass the primary concern.

items.stemText: The author of passage B would be most likely to agree with which one of the following statements?

options.optionContent: The desire to demonstrate that one is wealthier than others is a remnant of human beings' primeval past.
Very few people would be willing to accept a lower standard of living in return for greater relative wealth.
Being wealthier than other people would not make one happier if one believed that one's wealth was due merely to luck.
Gradual increases in employees' wages do not increase their job satisfaction.
The overall level of happiness in a society usually increases as the society becomes wealthier.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: Author B brings up this theory in the first paragraph, but then *rebuts* it (writing that “it is not the explanation best supported by the evidence”) in favor of the theory that what human beings *really* desire is to create value. So we can infer that author B *doesn’t* agree with this statement.

This conflicts with the findings of the Solnick and Hemenway study, which suggest that most people *would* be willing to accept a lower standard of living in return for greater relative wealth. Author B implicitly accepts these findings: the passage is spent offering an explanation for them, not refuting them. So we can infer that author B *doesn’t* agree with this statement.

Author B’s overall argument is that having more wealth than others is not what increases happiness—rather, it is the sense of having created value that leads to happiness, and when we create value, we are often rewarded with relative prosperity (i.e. wealth). In the third paragraph, author B states this directly: “it is the success—not the money per se—that provides the happiness. We use material wealth to show not just that we are prosperous, but that we are prosperous because we create value.” From this, we can infer that the author agrees that if one *didn’t* create value but is only wealthy by luck, this person would not be happier than others.

From passage B’s general argument, we can infer that author B believes that increases in wages likely reflect an increase in the value the employee creates, which *would* lead to greater happiness for the employee. However, happiness is not the same as job satisfaction, which author B never discusses. So we can’t be sure that author B would disagree or agree with this statement—it’s out of scope.

Author B doesn’t discuss the correlation between wealth and the *overall* happiness level of a society. Rather, author B’s argument focuses on explaining the correlation between *relative* wealth and happiness—why at any given time, people would prefer to be wealthier *than others* within that same society. So we can’t infer that the author would agree with this statement—it’s out of scope.

items.stemText: The author of passage B would be most likely to regard the conclusion that the Solnick and Hemenway study points to the existence of a "phenomenon of rivalry" (first sentence of the fourth paragraph of passage A) as

options.optionContent: ungenerous in its view of human nature and mistaken in its interpretation of the evidence
flattering in its implications about human nature but only weakly supported by the available evidence
plausible in its account of human nature but based largely upon ambiguous evidence
unflattering in its implications about human nature but more or less valid in the conclusions drawn from the evidence
accurate concerning human nature and strongly supported by the evidence

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: The Solnick and Hemenway study found that most people would rather have a low absolute income that is higher than everyone else’s than have a high absolute income that is lower than everyone else’s. Author A says that the phenomenon of rivalry explains these findings. But Author B argues that “the data show” something else—that there’s actually a more altruistic motive at work: “what scholars often portray as an ignoble tendency—wanting to have more than others—is really evidence of a desire to create value. Wanting to create value benefits society” (last paragraph of passage B). So Author B would likely view Author A’s conclusion of rivalry as both ungenerous (assuming “ignobility” in humans) and an incorrect interpretation of the findings.

Though the second part of this statement is somewhat supported, author B describes the rivalry explanation as *unflattering* in the last paragraph: “what scholars often portray as an ignoble tendency—wanting to have more than others—is really evidence of a desire to create value. Wanting to create value benefits society.”

There’s nothing to suggest that author B thinks the rivalry explanation is based on “ambiguous” evidence. Rather, author B thinks the value explanation is better supported by the data (second paragraph). Plus, author B does *not* think the rivalry explanation is plausible in its account of human nature. Most directly, we can see this in the last paragraph of passage B: “what scholars often portray as an ignoble tendency—wanting to have more than others—is really evidence of a desire to create value. Wanting to create value benefits society.”

Though the first part of this statement is supported, Author B does *not* think that the rivalry explanation is more or less valid in the conclusions drawn from the evidence—rather, author B thinks that the evidence best supports the value explanation (second paragraph).

Author B doesn’t think the rivalry explanation is accurate concerning human nature. Rather, author B thinks that what scholars often portray as an “ignoble” tendency in humans—the desire to have more wealth than others—is actually the altruistic desire to create value, which benefits society (last paragraph of passage B). And author B does *not* think that the rivalry explanation is strongly supported by the evidence—rather, author B thinks that the evidence best supports the value explanation (second paragraph).

items.stemText: Which one of the following pairs most accurately describes why the authors of passage A and passage B, respectively, mention the study by Solnick and Hemenway?

options.optionContent:
to present a view that will be argued against

to present a view for which additional evidence will be provided

to present a view that will be argued against

to provide evidence for one explanation of a phenomenon

to provide evidence for one explanation of a phenomenon

to present a view for which additional evidence will be provided

to provide evidence for one explanation of a phenomenon

to introduce the main topic to be discussed

to introduce the main topic to be discussed

to present a view that will be argued against

answerOptionExplanation.explanation:
Passage A brings up the Solnick and Hemenway study to provide evidence for the rivalry theory, which is one of two explanations given for the phenomenon of the rising income “norm.” Passage A never argues *against* the rivalry explanation, so the first reason in (A) doesn’t fit. 

Passage B focuses on *rebutting* (and *not*  providing additional evidence for) the rivalry explanation for Solnick and Hemenway’s findings. Most of passage B is devoted to arguing for an alternative explanation: the desire to create value. So for passage B, the study—which is only brought up at the beginning of the passage—serves as an introduction for the main topic, which is that people want to create value, and wealth only brings happiness inasmuch as it reflects having created value.

items.stemText: Which one of the following pairs of terms would most likely be used by the authors of passage A and passage B, respectively, to describe a person who wants to make more money than his or her neighbors?

options.optionContent: insular, cosmopolitan
altruistic, egocentric
happy, miserable
misguided, admirable
lucky, primitive

Author A discusses people’s desire to make more money than others in their “reference group” as the phenomenon of rivalry—which explains why happiness levels don’t increase as society grows richer over time. For example, writes author A, in East Germany, “living standards have soared since 1990, but the level of happiness has plummeted because people now compare themselves with West Germans, rather than with people in other Soviet bloc countries” (last sentence). We can infer from the author’s tone and overall argument that such comparers are **misguided**—that their viewpoint is **too narrow** and doesn’t take into account how their situation **has improved over time**. 

Author B, on the other hand, argues that “what scholars often portray as an ignoble tendency—wanting to have more than others—is really evidence of a desire to create value.” So we can infer that author B views these same comparers as **admirable.**

items.stimulusText:
Passage A

Research concerning happiness and wealth reveals a paradox: at any one time richer people report higher levels of happiness than poorer people in the same society report, and yet over time advanced societies have not grown happier as they have grown richer. Apparently, people are comparing their income with some norm, and that norm must be rising along with actual income. Two phenomena—habituation and rivalry—push up the norm.

When our living standards increase, we love it initially but then we adjust and it makes little difference. For example, if we ask people with different incomes what income they consider sufficient, the "required income" correlates strongly with their actual income: a rise in actual income causes a roughly equivalent rise in required income. We can also look at reported happiness over time. Job satisfaction depends little on the absolute level of wages but rises if wages rapidly increase.

We do not have the same experience with other aspects of our lives. We do not foresee how we adjust to material possessions, so we overinvest in acquiring them, at the expense of leisure.

Now consider the phenomenon of rivalry. In a study conducted by Solnick and Hemenway, people were asked to choose between two options, with all prices held constant:

A. You earn $50,000 a year while everyone else earns $25,000;

B. You earn $100,000 a year while others make $200,000.

The majority chose the first. They were happy to be poorer, provided their relative position improved.

And indeed, how people compare to their "reference group"—those most like them—is crucial for happiness. In East Germany, for example, living standards have soared since 1990, but the level of happiness has plummeted because people now compare themselves with West Germans, rather than with people in other Soviet bloc countries.

Passage B

Does the Solnick and Hemenway study mean that we care most about one-upmanship? Perhaps out of our primeval past comes the urge to demonstrate our superiority in order to help ensure mating prospects, keeping our genetic lines going. Still programmed like this, we get unexplainable pleasure from having a bigger house than our neighbors.

This theory may sound good and is commonly heard, but it is not the explanation best supported by the evidence. Rather, the data show that earning more makes people happier because relative prosperity makes them feel that they are successful, that they have created value.

If two people feel equally successful, they will be equally happy even if their incomes differ greatly. Of course, people who earn more generally view themselves as successful. But it is the success—not the money per se—that provides the happiness. We use material wealth to show not just that we are prosperous, but that we are prosperous because we create value.

What scholars often portray as an ignoble tendency—wanting to have more than others—is really evidence of a desire to create value. Wanting to create value benefits society. It is a bonus that it also brings happiness.
items.stemText: In arguing for their respective positions, the author of passage A and the author of passage B both do which one of the following?

options.optionContent: explain a phenomenon by pointing to its biological origins
endorse a claim simply because it is widely believed
accept a claim for the sake of argument
attempt to resolve an apparent paradox
assert that their positions are supported by data

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: Author A doesn’t discuss biological origins at all, let alone within an explanation for a phenomenon. And author B only offers up the biological-origin explanation to then *reject* it in favor of their own theory, which they believe is better supported by the data.
Neither author does this. Author A doesn’t discuss whether or not any of their claims are widely believed, and author B directly *rejects* a widely believed explanation in the second paragraph.
Neither author does this. Both authors argue for their own position without accepting any claim for the sake of argument.

Author A does this, but author B doesn’t try to resolve any “paradox”—rather, author B focuses on interpreting the findings of the Solnick and Hemenway study, offering a less common but better supported (in their opinion) alternative explanation for the results. In other words, author B doesn’t treat the findings, or the competing theories, as any kind of “paradox.”

Both authors do this. Author A brings up several different pieces of supporting evidence, albeit **implicitly**—he only names the Solnick and Hemenway study, but presumably the other evidence he cites (including the “required income” discussion and the East Germany discussion) come from studies as well. And author B directly asserts that “**the data show** that earning more makes people happier because relative prosperity makes them feel that they are successful, that they have created value.”

items.stimulusText:
It is generally believed that while in some cases government should intervene to protect people from risk—by imposing air safety standards, for example—in other cases, such as mountain climbing, the onus should be on the individual to protect himself or herself. In the eyes of the public at large, the demarcation between the two kinds of cases has mainly to do with whether the risk in question is incurred voluntarily. This distinction between voluntary and involuntary risk may in fact be the chief difference between lay and expert judgments about risk. Policy experts tend to focus on aggregate lives at stake; laypeople care a great deal whether a risk is undertaken voluntarily. However, judgments about whether a risk is "involuntary" often stem from confusion and selective attention, and the real reason for such judgments frequently lies in an antecedent judgment of some other kind. They are thus of little utility in guiding policy decisions.

First, it is not easy to determine when a risk is voluntarily incurred. Although voluntariness may be entirely absent in the case of an unforeseeable collision with an asteroid, with most environmental, occupational, and other social risks, it is not an all-or-nothing matter, but rather one of degree. Risks incurred by airline passengers are typically thought to be involuntary, since passengers have no control over whether a plane is going to crash. But they can choose airlines on the basis of safety records or choose not to fly. In characterizing the risks as involuntary, people focus on a small part of a complex interaction, not the decision to fly, but the accident when it occurs.

Second, people often characterize risks as "voluntary" when they do not approve of the purpose for which people run the risks. It is unlikely that people would want to pour enormous taxpayer resources into lowering the risks associated with skydiving, even if the ratio of dollars spent to lives saved were quite good. By contrast, people would probably not object to spending enormous resources on improving the safety of firefighters, even though the decision to become a firefighter is voluntary. In short, there is no special magic in notions like "voluntary" and "involuntary." Therefore, regulatory policy should be guided by a better understanding of the factors that underlie judgments about voluntariness.

In general, the government should attempt to save as many lives as it can, subject to the limited public and private resources devoted to risk reduction. Departures from this principle should be justified not by invoking the allegedly voluntary or involuntary nature of a particular risk, but rather by identifying the more specific considerations for which notions of voluntariness serve as proxies.
items.stemText: Which one of the following most accurately expresses the main point of the passage?

options.optionContent: In general, whether people characterize a risk as voluntary or involuntary depends on whether they approve of the purpose for which the risk is taken.
Decisions about government intervention to protect people from risks should be based primarily on how many lives can be saved rather than on whether the risks are considered voluntary.
Though laypeople may object, experts should be the ones to determine whether the risk incurred in a particular action is voluntary or involuntary.

Public-policy decisions related to the protection of society against risk are difficult to make because of the difficulty of distinguishing risks incurred voluntarily from those incurred involuntarily.
People who make judgments about the voluntary or involuntary character of a risk are usually unaware of the complicated motivations that lead people to take risks.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This is one of the flaws in voluntariness considerations that the author brings up, but it’s **too narrow** to encompass the main point. Rather, the main point is that the government shouldn’t use considerations of voluntariness to shape policy about protecting people from risks, and should instead shape such policy around saving as many people as possible.

This sums up the main point. The first paragraph states the thesis, that the government shouldn’t use considerations of voluntariness to shape risk intervention policy. The second and third paragraph further explains the author’s reasoning, and the last paragraph asserts that the government should instead shape policy around saving as many lives as it can.

This conflicts with the passage. The author believes that judgments about voluntariness are flawed, and are thus “of little utility in guiding policy decisions.” Whether or not experts or laypeople are doing the judging is irrelevant—and in fact, the author says that it’s mostly laypeople who care about voluntariness in the first place, while policy experts “tend to focus on aggregate lives at stake” (first paragraph).

The author neither states nor implies that public-policy decisions related to the protection of society against risk are difficult to make *in general*, let alone that distinguishing voluntariness from involuntariness is the reason—rather, the author argues that such decisions should *not* be based on voluntariness, and should instead be based on saving as many lives as possible. The difficulty of the decision-making is out of the scope of the passage.

First, this choice is too narrow. Purposes for taking risks are mentioned in paragraph three, but they are related to only **one** of the author's reasons (for why judgments about voluntariness are often really about something else). So this choice doesn't account for the reason discussed in paragraph two, and, more importantly, it doesn't account for the author's overall argument about what should guide policy decisions.

Also, this choice distorts the content of the passage. In paragraph three, the author suggests that people's judgement about voluntariness is influenced by whether they approve of the purpose for which people take risks. But the author does not suggest that people are "unaware" of those purposes.

items.questionType: Identifying Main Points and Primary Purposes
items.displayType: Identifying Main Points and Primary Purposes

items.stemText: The passage indicates that which one of the following is usually a significant factor in laypeople's willingness to support public funding for specific risk-reduction measures?

options.optionContent: an expectation about the ratio of dollars spent to lives saved
deference to expert judgments concerning whether the government should intervene
a belief as to whether the risk is incurred voluntarily or involuntarily
a judgment as to whether the risk puts a great number of lives at stake
a consideration of the total resources available for risk reduction

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This conflicts with the third paragraph, where the passage says that “it is unlikely that people would want to pour enormous taxpayer resources into lowering the risks associated with skydiving, even if the ratio of dollars spent to lives saved were quite good.” In other words, according to the passage, the ratio of dollars spent to lives saves is *not* a significant factor in laypeople's willingness to support public funding for specific risk-reduction measures

The passage doesn’t state or imply that laypeople ever defer to expert judgments; in fact, by saying that the considerations of the laypeople *differ* from the considerations of the experts (laypeople weigh voluntariness; experts weigh aggregate lives saved), the passage implies that laypeople *don’t* usually defer to expert judgments.

In the third paragraph, the author states that laypeople would be unwilling to pour enormous taxpayer resources into lowering the risks associated with skydiving, because they would categorize that as a “voluntary” risk (although, the author argues, what’s *really* going on is that they probably just don’t approve of skydiving as an activity). So we know that judgments about the voluntariness of the risk are usually a significant factor in laypeople's willingness to support public funding for specific risk-reduction measures.

This consideration is attributed to the *experts*, not the laypeople: “Policy experts tend to focus on aggregate lives at stake; laypeople care a great deal whether a risk is undertaken voluntarily” (first paragraph).

This isn’t described as a significant factor in laypeople's willingness to support public funding for specific risk-reduction measures. The *author* argues that the government should primarily factor in the number of lives saved, “subject to the limited public and private resources devoted to risk reduction.” But this doesn’t imply that a consideration of the resources is key for laypeople to support public funding.

items.stemText: According to the passage, which one of the following do laypeople generally consider to involve risk that is not freely assumed?

options.optionContent: traveling in outer space
participating in skydiving
serving as a firefighter
traveling in airplanes
climbing mountains

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: Though it’s not discussed in the passage, given that laypeople think skydiving involves voluntarily risk, they would likely think that traveling in outer space is a voluntary-risk activity as well.
Skydiving is considered a voluntary-risk activity by laypeople (third paragraph).

According to the passage, laypeople often characterize risks as "voluntary" when they do not approve of the purpose for which people run the risks. Skydiving is contrasted with firefighting in this regard, as skydiving doesn’t have an approved-of purpose, while firefighting does. However it’s still a personal choice to become a firefighter, and therefore the risk assumed is *not* totally involuntary (i.e., the risk is freely assumed). So if laypeople *say* that firefighting involves involuntary risk, what they *really* mean, according to the author, is that the risk is for an approved-of purpose—to put out fires.

The second paragraph states that “risks incurred by airline passengers are typically thought to be involuntary, since passengers have no control over whether a plane is going to crash.” In other words, laypeople generally consider traveling in airplanes as an activity that involves risks that are not freely assumed.

This conflicts with the passage. In the first paragraph we’re told that laypeople think the government shouldn’t intervene to protect people from risks associated with mountain climbing. Then we’re told that when laypeople think the government shouldn’t intervene to protect people from risks associated with an activity, it’s because they consider the risks involved in that activity to be voluntarily assumed. So we can infer that laypeople *do* consider mountain climbing to be an activity that involves freely assumed risk.

items.stemText: It can be inferred from the passage that the author would be most likely to agree with which one of the following statements?

options.optionContent: People should generally not be protected against the risks incurred through activities, such as skydiving, that are dangerous and serve no socially useful purpose.
The fact that plane crash victims chose to fly would usually be deemed by policy experts to be largely irrelevant to decisions about the government's role in regulating air safety.
Both the probability of occurrence and the probability of resulting death or injury are higher for plane crashes than for any other kind of risk incurred by airline passengers.
For public-policy purposes, a risk should be deemed voluntarily incurred if people are not subject to that risk unless they make a particular choice.
The main category of risk that is usually incurred completely involuntarily is the risk of natural disaster.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: According to the author, when it comes to risk-protection policy, the government should “attempt to save as many lives as it can,” and that any deviations from this policy shouldn’t be based on voluntariness but rather on more specific considerations (last paragraph). Whether or not an activity is dangerous and doesn’t serve a socially useful purpose is out of scope, so we can’t say that the author would agree with this statement.

According to the author, policy experts “tend to focus on aggregate lives at stake” rather than on the voluntariness of the risk (first paragraph). So the author would likely agree that, in making decisions about the government’s role in regulating air safety, the policy experts would *not* consider the fact that plane crash victims chose to fly.”
The author doesn’t ever discuss (let alone compare) different types risks incurred by airline passengers. So we can’t say that the author would agree with this statement.

The author argues that voluntariness should *not* be factored *at all* into risk-protection policy, as judgments about voluntariness are flawed. So we can’t say that the author would agree with this statement.

The author does imply that natural disasters are *one* example of a 100% involuntary-risk incurrence (second paragraph, in the discussion of an asteroid collision). But the author doesn’t say or imply that this is the “main” category of involuntary-risk incurrence—there are likely other events that the author would agree fits that bill. So this statement goes too far beyond what we can infer from the passage.

items.stemText: The author's use of the phrase "no special magic" (second to last sentence of the third paragraph) is most likely meant primarily to convey that notions like "voluntary" and "involuntary"

options.optionContent: do not exhaustively characterize the risks that people commonly face
have been used to intentionally conceal the factors motivating government efforts to protect people from risks
have no meaning beyond their literal, dictionary definitions
are mistakenly believed to be characteristics that inform people's understanding of the consequences of risk
provide a flawed mechanism for making public policy decisions relating to risk reduction

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: The author likely agrees that notions like "voluntary" and "involuntary" don’t exhaustively characterize the risks people commonly face, but that's not the purpose of saying that such notions have “no special magic.” Rather, the author means to convey that we can't rely on judgments about the voluntariness of incurring risk for guidance in shaping policy. Also, in this paragraph, the author isn’t talking about just risks that “people commonly face,” but also risks that are *not* commonly faced (such as the risks associated with skydiving and firefighting).

The author never states or implies that the notions of “voluntary” and “involuntary” have been used to *intentionally* conceal the factors motivating government efforts to protect people from risk. The author argues that judgments about the voluntariness of taking on risk—a paradigm often favored by *laypeople*—are flawed, and that they reflect other kinds of judgments (subconsciously) buried within them. But there's never any accusation of *intentionally* concealing the other factors at play, either on the part of the government, the policy experts, or the laypeople.

This is too strong. The author argues that when it comes to incurring risk, notions of “voluntary” and “involuntary” are very flawed—but not that these concepts have no meaning *at all* beyond their dictionary definitions. Rather, by stating that they have “no special magic” when it comes to policy decisions about risk intervention, the author means to convey that we can't rely on such judgments for guidance.

The author doesn't use the phrase “no special magic” to say anything about consequences. In fact, the *consequences* of risk are out of the scope of the passage entirely. Rather, the author means to convey that we can't rely on judgments about the voluntariness of incurring risks to shape policy.

The sentence concludes two paragraphs that each delve into a reason why the voluntariness of incurring risk isn’t a valuable tool for shaping public policy decisions—first, it’s difficult to nail down when a risk is voluntarily incurred in the first place; and second, people often (incorrectly) characterize risks as "voluntary" when they don’t approve of the purpose of taking the risk. Thus, that such judgments are flawed and can’t be used to guide risk-reduction policy is the author’s intention behind saying that these notions have “no special magic.”

items.stemText: The passage most strongly supports the inference that the author believes which one of the following?

options.optionContent: Whenever an activity involves the risk of loss of human life, the government should intervene to reduce the degree of risk incurred.
Some environmental risks are voluntary to a greater degree than others are.
Policy experts are more likely than laypeople to form an accurate judgment about the voluntariness or involuntariness of an activity.
The government should increase the quantity of resources devoted to protecting people from risk.
Government policies intended to reduce risk are not justified unless they comport with most people's beliefs.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: The author argues that risk-reduction policy should be based on saving **as many lives as possible**, subject to the limited resources devoted to risk reduction (last paragraph). So the author may not believe that an activity that involves the risk of just one or just a few lives merits any government intervention. Hence, we can’t infer that the author would agree with this statement.

In the second paragraph, the author argues that “with most environmental, occupational, and other social risks, [voluntariness] is not an all-or-nothing matter, but rather one of **degree**.” This implies that the author believes there are different degrees of voluntariness involved in environmental risks, with some involving more than others.

The author never implies that policy experts are more accurate in judgments about the voluntariness of risk than laypeople are—in fact, the author states that policy experts tend to “focus on aggregate lives at stake” instead of voluntariness (first paragraph). The author only claims that laypeople *care more* about voluntariness than experts.

In the last paragraph, the author writes that “the government should attempt to save as many lives as it can, subject to the limited public and private resources devoted to risk reduction.” The author never argues that these resources aren’t enough and should be increased—just that the government must work within the limits of what resources there are.

This choice conflicts with the author’s views. The author states that laypeople tend to care deeply about the voluntariness of the risk incurred, but then goes on to argue that such judgments are flawed and shouldn’t be used to guide policy, *despite* what these laypeople want. So it’s unlikely that the author would agree that policy should comport with most people’s beliefs.
